    "},{"template":{"inputPath":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","inputDir":"src","parsed":{"root":"","dir":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","stem":"index","path":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\src\\blog\\css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"extraOutputSubdirectory":"","outputDir":"public","linters":[],"transforms":[],"plugins":{},"paginationData":{},"isVerbose":true,"isDryRun":false,"writeCount":0,"skippedCount":0,"wrapWithLayouts":true,"fileSlug":{"inputPath":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","cleanInputPath":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","dirs":["blog","css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases"],"parsed":{"root":"","dir":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","stem":"index","path":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\blog\\css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"filenameNoExt":"index"},"fileSlugStr":"css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","filePathStem":"/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index","_templateRender":{"engineNameOrPath":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","inputDir":"src","includesDir":"src/_includes","parseMarkdownWith":"liquid","parseHtmlWith":"liquid","_engineName":"md","useMarkdown":true},"inputContent":"---\r\ndate: 2020-12-25\r\ntitle: Css flexbox and some use cases \r\nauthor: Spruce\r\nsummary: >\r\n Learn about css flex box and how to implement this layout model with some use cases \r\npreview: img/preview.png\r\nsharing:\r\n twitter: Css flexbox and some use cases\r\n facebook: Css flexbox and some use cases\r\n---\r\n\r\n

    \r\nIn this quick article, we are going to learn what and how to use css flexbox with some use cases of flexbox \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWhat is Css Flexbox?\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nIn the flex layout model, the children of a flex container can be laid in any direction, and can \"flex\" their sizes, either growing to fill unused space or shrinking to avoid overflowing the parent. Both horizontal and vertical alignment of the childern can be easily manipulated.\r\n\r\n- well thats according to the spec...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nfrom the css flexbox specification above, you see that flexbox is a layout model which can be used to lay out the children of a container easily... \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFlex Container\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThe flex container takes the css property and value display: flex or display: inline-flex and it is the box generated by an element with a computed display of flex, children of this container are called flex items\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFlex containers are not block containers ( containers that have \"display: block\" set on them), therefore some properties like:
    \r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nfloat, and clear\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nvertical-align\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\n::first-line and ::first-letter\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\nwill not have any effect on flex-items (you won't even know they are there)\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFloats and vertical-align css properties do not have any effect on flex items, \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 1\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 2\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n.flex-container {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  \r\n}\r\n.flex-item {\r\n  float: left; // this will have no effect\r\n  vertical-align: middle; // this will have no effect too\r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nFlex items\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\nhello i am a flex item too\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 1\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 2\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 3\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nHow many flex items do we have from the above code? Well you might say THREE, but its actually FOUR. Plain text that are not wrapped in any html tag are also regarded as flex items\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nFrom the preview(when display: flex; is added to the flex-container) above you see that Four items are laid out side by side, that means anything placed in a flex-container as a direct child is a flex item...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<!-- anything placed here as a direct child is a flex item -->\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n.flex-container {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  \r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nSome Flexbox Use Cases\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nFlexbox reponsive header\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nFlexbox can be used to solve many design problems both complex and simple design problems with a few lines of css, one of this is a responsive website header

    \r\ntake a look at the responsive website header below \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n{% codepen \"Spruce_khalifa\" \"Responsive header with flexbox\" \"ExgbxeP\" %}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFlexbox Card component\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nLets say you are creating a card component... \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n...and you always want the footer to stay at the bottom, no matter the length of your text... Yep css flexbox can do just that with a single line of code\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\narticle {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  flex-direction: column;\r\n}\r\n// styles for the header and footer\r\np {\r\n  flex-grow: 1;\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nCheck it out on codepen...\r\n
    \r\nyou just need to add the flex-grow: 1; to the card content and it will always grow to fill the available spaces\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n{% codepen \"Spruce_khalifa\" \"Flex grow\" \"GRjogZX\" %}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nOrdering Elements\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nSay you want to flip a component, like the Card component we created ealier, you want the footer part to come first and the header to go last, yep flexbox can do that...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n\r\n// styles for the component\r\n footer {\r\n  order: -1; // make the footer come first\r\n   }\r\n header {\r\n   order: 2; // make the header go last\r\n   }\r\n    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nthe main thing here is the order property here, the preview should look like this one below\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nCenter An Element\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nOne of the cool things about css flexbox is that you can center an element with ease \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<div class=\"c-card\">\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n</div>\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n\r\n// styles for the component\r\n .c-card {\r\n   // some css\r\n   display: flex;\r\n   align-items: center; // center item vertically\r\n   justify-content: center; // center item horizontally\r\n }\r\n    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nand boom that should do the trick...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\nBrowser Support\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nIf you want to support older browsers, you should check the browser support level from caniuse.com\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n{% caniuse \"flexbox\" %}\r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nOther Resources\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nCss flexbox W3c\r\n\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nComplete guide to css flexbox\r\n\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nagain thanks for reading...\r\n

    ","frontMatter":{"content":"\r\n

    \r\nIn this quick article, we are going to learn what and how to use css flexbox with some use cases of flexbox \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWhat is Css Flexbox?\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nIn the flex layout model, the children of a flex container can be laid in any direction, and can \"flex\" their sizes, either growing to fill unused space or shrinking to avoid overflowing the parent. Both horizontal and vertical alignment of the childern can be easily manipulated.\r\n\r\n- well thats according to the spec...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nfrom the css flexbox specification above, you see that flexbox is a layout model which can be used to lay out the children of a container easily... \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFlex Container\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThe flex container takes the css property and value display: flex or display: inline-flex and it is the box generated by an element with a computed display of flex, children of this container are called flex items\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFlex containers are not block containers ( containers that have \"display: block\" set on them), therefore some properties like:
    \r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nfloat, and clear\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nvertical-align\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\n::first-line and ::first-letter\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\nwill not have any effect on flex-items (you won't even know they are there)\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFloats and vertical-align css properties do not have any effect on flex items, \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 1\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 2\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n.flex-container {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  \r\n}\r\n.flex-item {\r\n  float: left; // this will have no effect\r\n  vertical-align: middle; // this will have no effect too\r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nFlex items\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\nhello i am a flex item too\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 1\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 2\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 3\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nHow many flex items do we have from the above code? Well you might say THREE, but its actually FOUR. Plain text that are not wrapped in any html tag are also regarded as flex items\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nFrom the preview(when display: flex; is added to the flex-container) above you see that Four items are laid out side by side, that means anything placed in a flex-container as a direct child is a flex item...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<!-- anything placed here as a direct child is a flex item -->\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n.flex-container {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  \r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nSome Flexbox Use Cases\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nFlexbox reponsive header\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nFlexbox can be used to solve many design problems both complex and simple design problems with a few lines of css, one of this is a responsive website header

    \r\ntake a look at the responsive website header below \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n{% codepen \"Spruce_khalifa\" \"Responsive header with flexbox\" \"ExgbxeP\" %}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFlexbox Card component\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nLets say you are creating a card component... \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n...and you always want the footer to stay at the bottom, no matter the length of your text... Yep css flexbox can do just that with a single line of code\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\narticle {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  flex-direction: column;\r\n}\r\n// styles for the header and footer\r\np {\r\n  flex-grow: 1;\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nCheck it out on codepen...\r\n
    \r\nyou just need to add the flex-grow: 1; to the card content and it will always grow to fill the available spaces\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n{% codepen \"Spruce_khalifa\" \"Flex grow\" \"GRjogZX\" %}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nOrdering Elements\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nSay you want to flip a component, like the Card component we created ealier, you want the footer part to come first and the header to go last, yep flexbox can do that...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n\r\n// styles for the component\r\n footer {\r\n  order: -1; // make the footer come first\r\n   }\r\n header {\r\n   order: 2; // make the header go last\r\n   }\r\n    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nthe main thing here is the order property here, the preview should look like this one below\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nCenter An Element\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nOne of the cool things about css flexbox is that you can center an element with ease \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<div class=\"c-card\">\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n</div>\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n\r\n// styles for the component\r\n .c-card {\r\n   // some css\r\n   display: flex;\r\n   align-items: center; // center item vertically\r\n   justify-content: center; // center item horizontally\r\n }\r\n    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nand boom that should do the trick...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\nBrowser Support\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nIf you want to support older browsers, you should check the browser support level from caniuse.com\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n{% caniuse \"flexbox\" %}\r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nOther Resources\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nCss flexbox W3c\r\n\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nComplete guide to css flexbox\r\n\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nagain thanks for reading...\r\n

    ","data":{"date":"2020-12-25T00:00:00.000Z","title":"Css flexbox and some use cases","author":"Spruce","summary":"Learn about css flex box and how to implement this layout model with some use cases \n","preview":"img/preview.png","sharing":{"twitter":"Css flexbox and some use cases","facebook":"Css flexbox and some use cases"}},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""},"_layoutKey":"layouts/posts.liquid","dataCache":{"layout":"layouts/posts.liquid","tags":["norm"],"date":"2020-12-25T00:00:00.000Z","title":"Css flexbox and some use cases","author":"Spruce","summary":"Learn about css flex box and how to implement this layout model with some use cases \n","preview":"img/preview.png","page":{"date":"2020-12-25T00:00:00.000Z","inputPath":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","fileSlug":"css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","filePathStem":"/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index","url":"/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/","outputPath":"public/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.html"}},"computedData":{"computed":{"page":{}},"templateStringKeyLookup":{"page.url":true,"page.outputPath":true},"computedKeys":{},"declaredDependencies":{"page.url":[],"page.outputPath":[]},"queue":{"graph":{"nodes":{},"outgoingEdges":{},"incomingEdges":{}}}}},"inputPath":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","fileSlug":"css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","filePathStem":"/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index","data":{"layout":"layouts/posts.liquid","date":"2020-12-25T00:00:00.000Z","title":"Css flexbox and some use cases","author":"Spruce","summary":"Learn about css flex box and how to implement this layout model with some use cases \n","preview":"img/preview.png"},"date":"2020-12-25T00:00:00.000Z","outputPath":"public/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.html","url":"/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/","templateContent":"

    \nIn this quick article, we are going to learn what and how to use css flexbox with some use cases of flexbox \n

    \n

    \nWhat is Css Flexbox?\n

    \n

    \n\nIn the flex layout model, the children of a flex container can be laid in any direction, and can \"flex\" their sizes, either growing to fill unused space or shrinking to avoid overflowing the parent. Both horizontal and vertical alignment of the childern can be easily manipulated.\n\n- well thats according to the spec...\n

    \n

    \nfrom the css flexbox specification above, you see that flexbox is a layout model which can be used to lay out the children of a container easily... \n

    \n

    \nFlex Container\n

    \n

    \nThe flex container takes the css property and value display: flex or display: inline-flex and it is the box generated by an element with a computed display of flex, children of this container are called flex items\n

    \n

    \nFlex containers are not block containers ( containers that have \"display: block\" set on them), therefore some properties like:
    \n

      \n
    1. \nfloat, and clear\n
      2. \n
    2. \nvertical-align\n
      3. \n
    3. \n::first-line and ::first-letter\n
      4. \n
    \nwill not have any effect on flex-items (you won't even know they are there)\n

    \n

    \nFloats and vertical-align css properties do not have any effect on flex items, \n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\nItem 1\n</li>\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\nItem 2\n</li>\n</ul>\n
    <!-- css codes -->\n.flex-container {\ndisplay: flex;
    \n
    }\n.flex-item {\nfloat: left; // this will have no effect\nvertical-align: middle; // this will have no effect too\n}\n\n

    \n

    \nFlex items\n

    \n
    \n\n
    <!-- html code -->\n<ul class="flex-container">\nhello i am a flex item too\n<li class="flex-item">\nItem 1\n</li>\n<li class="flex-item">\nItem 2\n</li>\n<li class="flex-item">\nItem 3\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n

    \n

    \nHow many flex items do we have from the above code? Well you might say THREE, but its actually FOUR. Plain text that are not wrapped in any html tag are also regarded as flex items\n

    \n\n

    \nFrom the preview(when display: flex; is added to the flex-container) above you see that Four items are laid out side by side, that means anything placed in a flex-container as a direct child is a flex item...\n

    \n 
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\n<!-- anything placed here as a direct child is a flex item -->\n</ul>\n\n<!-- css codes -->\n.flex-container {\n  display: flex;\n  \n}\n\n
    \n

    \nSome Flexbox Use Cases\n

    \n
    \nFlexbox reponsive header\n
    \n

    \nFlexbox can be used to solve many design problems both complex and simple design problems with a few lines of css, one of this is a responsive website header

    \ntake a look at the responsive website header below \n

    \n
    \n

    \n See the pen \n \n Responsive header with flexbox\n , by @Spruce_khalifa on Codepen\n

    \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFlexbox Card component\n
    \n

    \nLets say you are creating a card component... \n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<article class=\"flex-container\">\n<header>\n<!-- card header -->\n</header>\n<p>\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\n</p>\n<footer>\n<h2>\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\n</h2>\n</footer>\n</article>\n\n
    \n

    \n...and you always want the footer to stay at the bottom, no matter the length of your text... Yep css flexbox can do just that with a single line of code\n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<article>\n<header>\n<!-- card header -->\n</header>\n<p>\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\n</p>\n<footer>\n<h2>\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\n</h2>\n</footer>\n</article>\n
    <!-- css codes -->\narticle {\ndisplay: flex;\nflex-direction: column;\n}\n// styles for the header and footer\np {\nflex-grow: 1;\n}
    \n    \n
    \n

    \nCheck it out on codepen...\n
    \nyou just need to add the flex-grow: 1; to the card content and it will always grow to fill the available spaces\n

    \n
    \n

    \n See the pen \n \n Flex grow\n , by @Spruce_khalifa on Codepen\n

    \n
    \n
    \nOrdering Elements\n
    \n

    \nSay you want to flip a component, like the Card component we created ealier, you want the footer part to come first and the header to go last, yep flexbox can do that...\n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<article>\n<header>\n<!-- card header -->\n</header>\n<p>\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\n</p>\n<footer>\n<h2>\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\n</h2>\n</footer>\n</article>\n\n<!-- css codes -->\n\n// styles for the component\n footer {\n  order: -1; // make the footer come first\n   }\n header {\n   order: 2; // make the header go last\n   }\n    \n\n
    \n

    \nthe main thing here is the order property here, the preview should look like this one below\n

    \n\n

    \n
    \nCenter An Element\n
    \n

    \nOne of the cool things about css flexbox is that you can center an element with ease \n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<div class=\"c-card\">\n<article>\n<header>\n<!-- card header -->\n</header>\n<p>\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\n</p>\n<footer>\n<h2>\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\n</h2>\n</footer>\n</article>\n</div>\n<!-- css codes -->\n
    // styles for the component\n.c-card {\n// some css\ndisplay: flex;\nalign-items: center; // center item vertically\njustify-content: center; // center item horizontally\n}
    \n    \n
    \n

    \nand boom that should do the trick...\n

    \n\n
    \nBrowser Support\n
    \n

    \nIf you want to support older browsers, you should check the browser support level from caniuse.com\n

    \n

    \n

    \n

    \n \n \n \n \n \n

    \n

    \n
    \nOther Resources\n
    \n

    \n\nCss flexbox W3c\n\n

    \n

    \n\nComplete guide to css flexbox\n\n

    \n

    \nagain thanks for reading...\n

    ","_templateContent":"

    \nIn this quick article, we are going to learn what and how to use css flexbox with some use cases of flexbox \n

    \n

    \nWhat is Css Flexbox?\n

    \n

    \n\nIn the flex layout model, the children of a flex container can be laid in any direction, and can \"flex\" their sizes, either growing to fill unused space or shrinking to avoid overflowing the parent. Both horizontal and vertical alignment of the childern can be easily manipulated.\n\n- well thats according to the spec...\n

    \n

    \nfrom the css flexbox specification above, you see that flexbox is a layout model which can be used to lay out the children of a container easily... \n

    \n

    \nFlex Container\n

    \n

    \nThe flex container takes the css property and value display: flex or display: inline-flex and it is the box generated by an element with a computed display of flex, children of this container are called flex items\n

    \n

    \nFlex containers are not block containers ( containers that have \"display: block\" set on them), therefore some properties like:
    \n

      \n
    1. \nfloat, and clear\n
      2. \n
    2. \nvertical-align\n
      3. \n
    3. \n::first-line and ::first-letter\n
      4. \n
    \nwill not have any effect on flex-items (you won't even know they are there)\n

    \n

    \nFloats and vertical-align css properties do not have any effect on flex items, \n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\nItem 1\n</li>\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\nItem 2\n</li>\n</ul>\n
    <!-- css codes -->\n.flex-container {\ndisplay: flex;
    \n
    }\n.flex-item {\nfloat: left; // this will have no effect\nvertical-align: middle; // this will have no effect too\n}\n\n

    \n

    \nFlex items\n

    \n
    \n\n
    <!-- html code -->\n<ul class="flex-container">\nhello i am a flex item too\n<li class="flex-item">\nItem 1\n</li>\n<li class="flex-item">\nItem 2\n</li>\n<li class="flex-item">\nItem 3\n</li>\n</ul>\n\n

    \n

    \nHow many flex items do we have from the above code? Well you might say THREE, but its actually FOUR. Plain text that are not wrapped in any html tag are also regarded as flex items\n

    \n\n

    \nFrom the preview(when display: flex; is added to the flex-container) above you see that Four items are laid out side by side, that means anything placed in a flex-container as a direct child is a flex item...\n

    \n 
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\n<!-- anything placed here as a direct child is a flex item -->\n</ul>\n\n<!-- css codes -->\n.flex-container {\n  display: flex;\n  \n}\n\n
    \n

    \nSome Flexbox Use Cases\n

    \n
    \nFlexbox reponsive header\n
    \n

    \nFlexbox can be used to solve many design problems both complex and simple design problems with a few lines of css, one of this is a responsive website header

    \ntake a look at the responsive website header below \n

    \n
    \n

    \n See the pen \n \n Responsive header with flexbox\n , by @Spruce_khalifa on Codepen\n

    \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFlexbox Card component\n
    \n

    \nLets say you are creating a card component... \n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<article class=\"flex-container\">\n<header>\n<!-- card header -->\n</header>\n<p>\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\n</p>\n<footer>\n<h2>\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\n</h2>\n</footer>\n</article>\n\n
    \n

    \n...and you always want the footer to stay at the bottom, no matter the length of your text... Yep css flexbox can do just that with a single line of code\n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<article>\n<header>\n<!-- card header -->\n</header>\n<p>\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\n</p>\n<footer>\n<h2>\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\n</h2>\n</footer>\n</article>\n
    <!-- css codes -->\narticle {\ndisplay: flex;\nflex-direction: column;\n}\n// styles for the header and footer\np {\nflex-grow: 1;\n}
    \n    \n
    \n

    \nCheck it out on codepen...\n
    \nyou just need to add the flex-grow: 1; to the card content and it will always grow to fill the available spaces\n

    \n
    \n

    \n See the pen \n \n Flex grow\n , by @Spruce_khalifa on Codepen\n

    \n
    \n
    \nOrdering Elements\n
    \n

    \nSay you want to flip a component, like the Card component we created ealier, you want the footer part to come first and the header to go last, yep flexbox can do that...\n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<article>\n<header>\n<!-- card header -->\n</header>\n<p>\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\n</p>\n<footer>\n<h2>\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\n</h2>\n</footer>\n</article>\n\n<!-- css codes -->\n\n// styles for the component\n footer {\n  order: -1; // make the footer come first\n   }\n header {\n   order: 2; // make the header go last\n   }\n    \n\n
    \n

    \nthe main thing here is the order property here, the preview should look like this one below\n

    \n\n

    \n
    \nCenter An Element\n
    \n

    \nOne of the cool things about css flexbox is that you can center an element with ease \n

    \n
    \n\n<!-- html code -->\n<div class=\"c-card\">\n<article>\n<header>\n<!-- card header -->\n</header>\n<p>\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\n</p>\n<footer>\n<h2>\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\n</h2>\n</footer>\n</article>\n</div>\n<!-- css codes -->\n
    // styles for the component\n.c-card {\n// some css\ndisplay: flex;\nalign-items: center; // center item vertically\njustify-content: center; // center item horizontally\n}
    \n    \n
    \n

    \nand boom that should do the trick...\n

    \n\n
    \nBrowser Support\n
    \n

    \nIf you want to support older browsers, you should check the browser support level from caniuse.com\n

    "},{"template":{"inputPath":"./src/blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021/index.md","inputDir":"src","parsed":{"root":"","dir":"./src/blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"./src/blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021","stem":"index","path":"./src/blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\src\\blog\\top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"extraOutputSubdirectory":"","outputDir":"public","linters":[],"transforms":[],"plugins":{},"paginationData":{},"isVerbose":true,"isDryRun":false,"writeCount":0,"skippedCount":0,"wrapWithLayouts":true,"fileSlug":{"inputPath":"blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021/index.md","cleanInputPath":"blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021/index.md","dirs":["blog","top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021"],"parsed":{"root":"","dir":"blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021","stem":"index","path":"blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\blog\\top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"filenameNoExt":"index"},"fileSlugStr":"top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021","filePathStem":"/blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021/index","_templateRender":{"engineNameOrPath":"./src/blog/top-5-css-methodologies-in-2021/index.md","inputDir":"src","includesDir":"src/_includes","parseMarkdownWith":"liquid","parseHtmlWith":"liquid","_engineName":"md","useMarkdown":true},"inputContent":"---\r\ndate: 2020-12-26\r\ntitle: Top 5 Css Methodologies In 2021 \r\nauthor: Spruce\r\nsummary: >\r\n See the top 5 css methodologies in 2021 \r\npreview: img/preview.jpg\r\nsharing:\r\n twitter: Top 5 Css Methodologies In 2021\r\n facebook: Top 5 Css Methodologies In 2021\r\n---\r\n\r\nCss is very difficult to manage when you are dealing with a large system, this is because Everything in css is Global\r\n\r\n
    \r\n  \r\n\r\n<button class=\"button button-action\">\r\n    Load More\r\n  </button>\r\n\r\n  <!-- css -->\r\n\r\n  .button {\r\n    background: blue;\r\n  }\r\n  .button-action {\r\n    background: pink;\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  // then maybe after 3 months on line 1299...\r\n  // another developer wants a call to action button\r\n  // and he declares another class with button-action with background color red\r\n\r\n  .button-action {\r\n    background: red;\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n you might be wondering what will be the background color of the button, well like i said earlier everything in css is Global, what will happen is that all three background properties will move to the top of the Scope like this...\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nbackground: blue;\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nbackground: pink;\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nbackground: red;\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nThen the browser will go through the code and apply all of them. Yeah all of them, and then decide to use the last one\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n  \r\n \r\n // the browser will read the code like this from top to bottom\r\n\r\n  <!-- css -->\r\n\r\n   background: blue; // oh here is a background with color of blue, use this.\r\n\r\n   background: pink; // wait, don't use that, here is another background with color pink, definately use this.\r\n\r\n   background: red; // what's wrong with this developer, here is another background with color red, jeez, is there another one?. nope, then use this.\r\n\r\n    <!-- Html -->\r\n\r\n    <button class=\"button button-action\">\r\n    Load More\r\n  >/button>\r\n\r\n  \r\n
    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nThe problem of managing css is what every developer must face one way or the other, not to mention (one of the hardest thing in css) naming classes, along the line you are going to run out of class names, that's where css methodologies comes in play(sticking to a particular naming convention)... \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWhat are css methodologies?\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\ncss methodologies are systems that are formaly documented down that help us to auhor/write css as isolated modules, rather than just some long indivisible code.\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nTop 5 Css Methodologies in 2021\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n1. Atomic Css\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nAtomic Css is a collection of single purpose styling units that fits well with components in templated framewoks...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nBenefits of using Atomic Css\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nMoves specifity out of the way\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nImproves performance\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nAllows to share content and assets easily\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFurther reading \r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nAtomic css frequently asked questions\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nAtomic Css Quick Start\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n2. BEM\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nBEM stands for - BLOCKS, ELEMENTS and MODIFIERS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nBlock:
    \r\nThis are standalone entity that is meaningful on its own

    \r\nElement:
    \r\nA part of a block that has no standalone meaning (it must be used within a block)

    \r\nModifier:
    \r\nA flag on a block or element, basically we use this to change the appearance or state of an element.\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nBenefits of using BEM\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nModularity\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nReusability\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nStructure\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFurther reading \r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nIntro to BEM\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nBEM\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nBEM naming convention\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n3. ITCSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nITCSS - stands for INVERTED TRIANGLE CSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThis is a methodolgy for structuring your css files in the best and stress free way as possible.\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nBenefits of using ITCSS\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nLess thinking on naming things\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nReusability\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nFlexibility\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nFurther reading \r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nITCSS: Scalable and Maintainable Css Architecture\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nIntro to ITCSS for web developers\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\n4. SMACSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nSMACSS stands for - SCALABLE and MODULAR ARCHITECTURE for CSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nBenefits of using SMACSS\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nScalable\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nEase of Reading\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nFurther reading \r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nSmacss guide\r\n
      2. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n5. OOCSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nOOCSS stands for - OBJECT ORIENTED CSS\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nTwo main principles of OOCSS\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nSeparating Structure From Skin\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nSeparating Container And Content\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nBenefits of using OOCSS\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nMaintainable stylesheets\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nFaster websites\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nEasier to modify common styles\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFurther reading \r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nObject oriented Css\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nIntro to object oriented css on smashingmagazine\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nThis list is based on the survey from The state of css 2020, and it is intended to show you the css methodologies that would probably be used in 2021 \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nAnother css methodology that is currently on a fast rise is the Cube Css\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n Note: There is no best css methodology, the one you decide to use depends on you and the type of your project...\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nThanks for reading\r\n

    ","frontMatter":{"content":"\r\nCss is very difficult to manage when you are dealing with a large system, this is because Everything in css is Global\r\n\r\n
    \r\n  \r\n\r\n<button class=\"button button-action\">\r\n    Load More\r\n  </button>\r\n\r\n  <!-- css -->\r\n\r\n  .button {\r\n    background: blue;\r\n  }\r\n  .button-action {\r\n    background: pink;\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  // then maybe after 3 months on line 1299...\r\n  // another developer wants a call to action button\r\n  // and he declares another class with button-action with background color red\r\n\r\n  .button-action {\r\n    background: red;\r\n  }\r\n\r\n  \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n you might be wondering what will be the background color of the button, well like i said earlier everything in css is Global, what will happen is that all three background properties will move to the top of the Scope like this...\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nbackground: blue;\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nbackground: pink;\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nbackground: red;\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nThen the browser will go through the code and apply all of them. Yeah all of them, and then decide to use the last one\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n  \r\n \r\n // the browser will read the code like this from top to bottom\r\n\r\n  <!-- css -->\r\n\r\n   background: blue; // oh here is a background with color of blue, use this.\r\n\r\n   background: pink; // wait, don't use that, here is another background with color pink, definately use this.\r\n\r\n   background: red; // what's wrong with this developer, here is another background with color red, jeez, is there another one?. nope, then use this.\r\n\r\n    <!-- Html -->\r\n\r\n    <button class=\"button button-action\">\r\n    Load More\r\n  >/button>\r\n\r\n  \r\n
    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nThe problem of managing css is what every developer must face one way or the other, not to mention (one of the hardest thing in css) naming classes, along the line you are going to run out of class names, that's where css methodologies comes in play(sticking to a particular naming convention)... \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWhat are css methodologies?\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\ncss methodologies are systems that are formaly documented down that help us to auhor/write css as isolated modules, rather than just some long indivisible code.\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nTop 5 Css Methodologies in 2021\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n1. Atomic Css\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nAtomic Css is a collection of single purpose styling units that fits well with components in templated framewoks...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nBenefits of using Atomic Css\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nMoves specifity out of the way\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nImproves performance\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nAllows to share content and assets easily\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFurther reading \r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nAtomic css frequently asked questions\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nAtomic Css Quick Start\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n2. BEM\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nBEM stands for - BLOCKS, ELEMENTS and MODIFIERS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nBlock:
    \r\nThis are standalone entity that is meaningful on its own

    \r\nElement:
    \r\nA part of a block that has no standalone meaning (it must be used within a block)

    \r\nModifier:
    \r\nA flag on a block or element, basically we use this to change the appearance or state of an element.\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nBenefits of using BEM\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nModularity\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nReusability\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nStructure\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFurther reading \r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nIntro to BEM\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nBEM\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nBEM naming convention\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n3. ITCSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nITCSS - stands for INVERTED TRIANGLE CSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThis is a methodolgy for structuring your css files in the best and stress free way as possible.\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nBenefits of using ITCSS\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nLess thinking on naming things\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nReusability\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nFlexibility\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nFurther reading \r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nITCSS: Scalable and Maintainable Css Architecture\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nIntro to ITCSS for web developers\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nSMACSS stands for - SCALABLE and MODULAR ARCHITECTURE for CSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nBenefits of using SMACSS\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nScalable\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nEase of Reading\r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nSmacss guide\r\n
      2. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n5. OOCSS\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nOOCSS stands for - OBJECT ORIENTED CSS\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nTwo main principles of OOCSS\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nSeparating Structure From Skin\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nSeparating Container And Content\r\n

    Css is very difficult to manage when you are dealing with a large system, this is because Everything in css is Global

    \n
    \n  \n\n<button class=\"button button-action\">\n    Load More\n  </button>\n\n  <!-- css -->\n\n  .button {\n    background: blue;\n  }\n  .button-action {\n    background: pink;\n  }\n\n  // then maybe after 3 months on line 1299...\n  // another developer wants a call to action button\n  // and he declares another class with button-action with background color red\n\n  .button-action {\n    background: red;\n  }\n\n  \n
    \n

    \n you might be wondering what will be the background color of the button, well like i said earlier everything in css is Global, what will happen is that all three background properties will move to the top of the Scope like this...\n

    \n
      \n
    1. \nbackground: blue;\n
      2. \n
    2. \nbackground: pink;\n
      3. \n
    3. \nbackground: red;\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \nThen the browser will go through the code and apply all of them. Yeah all of them, and then decide to use the last one\n

    \n
    \n  \n
    // the browser will read the code like this from top to bottom
    \n
    <!-- css -->
    \n
    background: blue; // oh here is a background with color of blue, use this.
    \n
    background: pink; // wait, don't use that, here is another background with color pink, definately use this.
    \n
    background: red; // what's wrong with this developer, here is another background with color red, jeez, is there another one?. nope, then use this.
    \n
    &lt;!-- Html --&gt;\n\n&lt;button class="button button-action"&gt;\nLoad More\n
    \n
    >/button>
    \n      \n
    \n\n

    \nThe problem of managing css is what every developer must face one way or the other, not to mention (one of the hardest thing in css) naming classes, along the line you are going to run out of class names, that's where css methodologies comes in play(sticking to a particular naming convention)... \n

    \n

    \nWhat are css methodologies?\n

    \n

    \ncss methodologies are systems that are formaly documented down that help us to auhor/write css as isolated modules, rather than just some long indivisible code.\n

    \n

    \nTop 5 Css Methodologies in 2021\n

    \n

    \n1. Atomic Css\n

    \n

    \nAtomic Css is a collection of single purpose styling units that fits well with components in templated framewoks...\n

    \n

    \n
    \nBenefits of using Atomic Css\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nMoves specifity out of the way\n
      2. \n
    2. \nImproves performance\n
      3. \n
    3. \nAllows to share content and assets easily\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nAtomic css frequently asked questions\n
      2. \n
    2. \nAtomic Css Quick Start\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n

    \n2. BEM\n

    \n

    \nBEM stands for - BLOCKS, ELEMENTS and MODIFIERS\n

    \n

    \nBlock:
    \nThis are standalone entity that is meaningful on its own

    \nElement:
    \nA part of a block that has no standalone meaning (it must be used within a block)

    \nModifier:
    \nA flag on a block or element, basically we use this to change the appearance or state of an element.\n

    \n
    \nBenefits of using BEM\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nModularity\n
      2. \n
    2. \nReusability\n
      3. \n
    3. \nStructure\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nIntro to BEM\n
      2. \n
    2. \nBEM\n
      3. \n
    3. \nBEM naming convention\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n

    \n3. ITCSS\n

    \n

    \nITCSS - stands for INVERTED TRIANGLE CSS\n

    \n

    \nThis is a methodolgy for structuring your css files in the best and stress free way as possible.\n

    \n
    \nBenefits of using ITCSS\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nLess thinking on naming things\n
      2. \n
    2. \nReusability\n
      3. \n
    3. \nFlexibility\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nITCSS: Scalable and Maintainable Css Architecture\n
      2. \n
    2. \nIntro to ITCSS for web developers\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n

    \n4. SMACSS\n

    \n

    \nSMACSS stands for - SCALABLE and MODULAR ARCHITECTURE for CSS\n

    \n

    \n

    \nBenefits of using SMACSS\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nScalable\n
      2. \n
    2. \nEase of Reading\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nSmacss guide\n
      2. \n
    \n

    \n

    \n5. OOCSS\n

    \n

    \nOOCSS stands for - OBJECT ORIENTED CSS\n

    \n
    \nTwo main principles of OOCSS\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nSeparating Structure From Skin\n
      2. \n
    2. \nSeparating Container And Content\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nBenefits of using OOCSS\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nMaintainable stylesheets\n
      2. \n

    ","_templateContent":"

    Css is very difficult to manage when you are dealing with a large system, this is because Everything in css is Global

    \n
    \n  \n\n<button class=\"button button-action\">\n    Load More\n  </button>\n\n  <!-- css -->\n\n  .button {\n    background: blue;\n  }\n  .button-action {\n    background: pink;\n  }\n\n  // then maybe after 3 months on line 1299...\n  // another developer wants a call to action button\n  // and he declares another class with button-action with background color red\n\n  .button-action {\n    background: red;\n  }\n\n  \n
    \n

    \n you might be wondering what will be the background color of the button, well like i said earlier everything in css is Global, what will happen is that all three background properties will move to the top of the Scope like this...\n

    \n
      \n
    1. \nbackground: blue;\n
      2. \n
    2. \nbackground: pink;\n
      3. \n
    3. \nbackground: red;\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \nThen the browser will go through the code and apply all of them. Yeah all of them, and then decide to use the last one\n

    \n
    \n  \n
    // the browser will read the code like this from top to bottom
    \n
    <!-- css -->
    \n
    background: blue; // oh here is a background with color of blue, use this.
    \n
    background: pink; // wait, don't use that, here is another background with color pink, definately use this.
    \n
    background: red; // what's wrong with this developer, here is another background with color red, jeez, is there another one?. nope, then use this.
    \n
    &lt;!-- Html --&gt;\n\n&lt;button class="button button-action"&gt;\nLoad More\n
    \n
    >/button>
    \n      \n
    \n\n

    \nThe problem of managing css is what every developer must face one way or the other, not to mention (one of the hardest thing in css) naming classes, along the line you are going to run out of class names, that's where css methodologies comes in play(sticking to a particular naming convention)... \n

    \n

    \nWhat are css methodologies?\n

    \n

    \ncss methodologies are systems that are formaly documented down that help us to auhor/write css as isolated modules, rather than just some long indivisible code.\n

    \n

    \nTop 5 Css Methodologies in 2021\n

    \n

    \n1. Atomic Css\n

    \n

    \nAtomic Css is a collection of single purpose styling units that fits well with components in templated framewoks...\n

    \n

    \n
    \nBenefits of using Atomic Css\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nMoves specifity out of the way\n
      2. \n
    2. \nImproves performance\n
      3. \n
    3. \nAllows to share content and assets easily\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nAtomic css frequently asked questions\n
      2. \n
    2. \nAtomic Css Quick Start\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n

    \n2. BEM\n

    \n

    \nBEM stands for - BLOCKS, ELEMENTS and MODIFIERS\n

    \n

    \nBlock:
    \nThis are standalone entity that is meaningful on its own

    \nElement:
    \nA part of a block that has no standalone meaning (it must be used within a block)

    \nModifier:
    \nA flag on a block or element, basically we use this to change the appearance or state of an element.\n

    \n
    \nBenefits of using BEM\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nModularity\n
      2. \n
    2. \nReusability\n
      3. \n
    3. \nStructure\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nIntro to BEM\n
      2. \n
    2. \nBEM\n
      3. \n
    3. \nBEM naming convention\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n

    \n3. ITCSS\n

    \n

    \nITCSS - stands for INVERTED TRIANGLE CSS\n

    \n

    \nThis is a methodolgy for structuring your css files in the best and stress free way as possible.\n

    \n
    \nBenefits of using ITCSS\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nLess thinking on naming things\n
      2. \n
    2. \nReusability\n
      3. \n
    3. \nFlexibility\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nITCSS: Scalable and Maintainable Css Architecture\n
      2. \n
    2. \nIntro to ITCSS for web developers\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n

    \n4. SMACSS\n

    \n

    \nSMACSS stands for - SCALABLE and MODULAR ARCHITECTURE for CSS\n

    \n

    \n

    \nBenefits of using SMACSS\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nScalable\n
      2. \n
    2. \nEase of Reading\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nSmacss guide\n
      2. \n
    \n

    \n

    \n5. OOCSS\n

    \n

    \nOOCSS stands for - OBJECT ORIENTED CSS\n

    \n
    \nTwo main principles of OOCSS\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nSeparating Structure From Skin\n
      2. \n
    2. \nSeparating Container And Content\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nBenefits of using OOCSS\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nMaintainable stylesheets\n
      2. \n
    2. \nFaster websites\n
      3. \n
    3. \nEasier to modify common styles\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n
    \nFurther reading \n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nObject oriented Css\n
      2. \n
    2. \nIntro to object oriented css on smashingmagazine\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n

    \nThis list is based on the survey from The state of css 2020, and it is intended to show you the css methodologies that would probably be used in 2021 \n

    \n

    \nAnother css methodology that is currently on a fast rise is the Cube Css\n

    \n
    \n
    \n Note: There is no best css methodology, the one you decide to use depends on you and the type of your project...\n
    \n
    \n

    \nThanks for reading\n

    "},{"template":{"inputPath":"./src/blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects/index.md","inputDir":"src","parsed":{"root":"","dir":"./src/blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"./src/blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects","stem":"index","path":"./src/blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\src\\blog\\5-cool-css-only-line-effects\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"extraOutputSubdirectory":"","outputDir":"public","linters":[],"transforms":[],"plugins":{},"paginationData":{},"isVerbose":true,"isDryRun":false,"writeCount":0,"skippedCount":0,"wrapWithLayouts":true,"fileSlug":{"inputPath":"blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects/index.md","cleanInputPath":"blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects/index.md","dirs":["blog","5-cool-css-only-line-effects"],"parsed":{"root":"","dir":"blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects","stem":"index","path":"blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\blog\\5-cool-css-only-line-effects\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"filenameNoExt":"index"},"fileSlugStr":"5-cool-css-only-line-effects","filePathStem":"/blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects/index","_templateRender":{"engineNameOrPath":"./src/blog/5-cool-css-only-line-effects/index.md","inputDir":"src","includesDir":"src/_includes","parseMarkdownWith":"liquid","parseHtmlWith":"liquid","_engineName":"md","useMarkdown":true},"inputContent":"---\r\ndate: 2021-01-01\r\ntitle: How to create 5 Cool Css only line effect\r\nauthor: Spruce\r\nauthorLink: spruce.emma\r\nsummary: 'Who said css lines has to be boring? Or just a straight line'\r\npreview: img/preview.png\r\nsharing:\r\n twitter: How to create 5 Cool Css only line effect\r\n facebook: How to create 5 Cool Css only line effect\r\n--- \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWhen we talk about css lines we shouldn't always think about ordinary \"one way straight lines\"\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nLines can be used to style up our web pages in a lot of ways. That is, just 5 effects are just a few things you could do with Lines\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWhat would make this effects fun is that you only get to use CSS, no images are used here\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNote: Some of this effect can be achieved using images too\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nCss only Line effects\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\n \r\nHighlight Text\r\n\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\n \r\nLines on both side of an Element\r\n\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\n \r\nCss Wavy line\r\n\r\n
      4. \r\n
    4. \r\n \r\nLine Hover Effect\r\n\r\n
      5. \r\n
    5. \r\n \r\nAdd line in the middle of a word\r\n\r\n
      6. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nLet's jump right into actually creating this stuff\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nHighlight Text\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nNow you might be surprised how easy it is to highlight a whole paragraph of text with one line of css...\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n // HTML code\r\n <p class=\"highlight-text\">\r\n  Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. At nam dignissimos nemo nihil iure illo nisi nobis voluptatum sit architecto reprehenderit, quibusdam molestiae, sunt, distinctio ea vero? Error, minus excepturi?\r\n <p>\r\n\r\n// Css \r\n// Only trick here is to make sure the element is inline\r\n\r\n .highlight-text {\r\n display: inline; // enforce inline\r\nbackground: linear-gradient(180deg, rgba(225,225,225,0) 50%, #00bb00 50%);\r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nAnd that's it, preview should look like this\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. At nam dignissimos nemo nihil iure illo nisi nobis voluptatum sit architecto reprehenderit, quibusdam molestiae, sunt, distinctio ea vero? Error, minus excepturi? \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nLines on both side of an Element\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nYou might be wondering, how do I place lines on both side of an Element in the most less messy way. It's actually kind of a breeze with css LINEAR-GRADIENT\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n // HTML code\r\n  <div class=\"lines\">\r\n    <input type=\"submit\" class=\"btn btn--small btn--primary\" value=\"button\">\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n// Css \r\n\r\n .lines {\r\n    text-align: center;\r\n    background-image: linear-gradient(#ddd,#ddd);\r\n    background-size: 100% .1em;\r\n    background-repeat: no-repeat;\r\n    background-position: center center;\r\n    margin: 2em 0;\r\n}\r\n.llines .btn\r\n {\r\n display:inline-block;\r\n box-shadow:0 0 0 1em #fff;\r\n} \r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    that's it, the preview should look like this\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nCss Wavy lines\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWith just a single div you can create a Wavy effect with pure css\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n // HTML code\r\n <div class=\"wavy-line\"><div>\r\n\r\n// Css\r\n\r\n.wavy-line {\r\n    position: relative;\r\n    width: 100vw;\r\n    height: 50px;\r\n}\r\n.wavy-line::before, .line::after {\r\n    content: \"\";\r\n    display: block;\r\n    position: absolute;\r\n    width: 100vw; /*same width as container*/\r\n    height: 26px;\r\n}\r\n.wavy-line::after {\r\n    background: linear-gradient(45deg, transparent, transparent 49%, green 49%, transparent 51%);\r\n}\r\n.wavy-line::before {\r\n    background: linear-gradient(-45deg, transparent, transparent 49%, green 49%, transparent 51%);\r\n}\r\n.wavy-line::before, .line::after {\r\n    background-size: 50px 50px;\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nThere you go, and the preview should look like the one below\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nAnimate line on hover\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nAnother cool thing you can do with css lines is animating them....\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n // HTML code\r\n     <a href=\"#0\" class=\"line-animate\">\r\n        hover me\r\n    </a>\r\n\r\n// Css\r\n\r\n.line-animate {\r\n    display: inline-block;\r\n    text-decoration: none;\r\n    font-size: 26px;\r\n    color: green;\r\n    position: relative;\r\n}\r\n.line-animate:hover.line-animate::after {\r\n    content: \"\";\r\n    display: block;\r\n    width: 100%;\r\n    height: 4px;\r\n    position: absolute;\r\n    top: 100%;\r\n    background-image: linear-gradient(#ddd,#ddd);\r\n    background-size: 100% .1em;\r\n    animation: animate .5s linear;\r\n\r\n}\r\n\r\n@keyframes animate {\r\n    0% {\r\n        width: 0;\r\n    }\r\n    50% {\r\n        width: 100%;\r\n    }\r\n    0% {\r\n        width: 0;\r\n    }\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n \r\n hover me\r\n \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nAnd there you have it, a cool hover line effect created with css\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nAdd line in the middle of a word\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nHave you ever wanted create a header text like the one below?\r\n

    \r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWhat if I told you it is quite easy to do with CSS \r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n // HTML code\r\n   <div class=\"line-before\">\r\n     <span class=\"line-before__inner\">\r\n     Latest posts\r\n    </span>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n// Css \r\n.line-before__inner {\r\n position:relative;\r\n display:block;\r\n width:100%;\r\n color:#333;\r\n background-position:center;\r\n z-index:2;\r\n padding-left:calc(100px + 1em);\r\n}\r\n\r\n.line-before__inner::before {\r\n content:'';\r\n position:absolute;\r\n display:block;\r\n width:100px;\r\n height:1px;\r\n background-color:currentColor;\r\n left:0;\r\n top:50%\r\n} \r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n \r\n Latest posts\r\n \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThe CSS above is self explanatory, so that's how to add a line in the middle of a text item\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nThanks for reading\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNote: Some of this effect can be achieved using images too\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nCss only Line effects\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\n \r\nHighlight Text\r\n\r\n

    \r\n

Error, minus excepturi?\r\n <p>\r\n\r\n// Css \r\n// Only trick here is to make sure the element is inline\r\n\r\n .highlight-text {\r\n display: inline; // enforce inline\r\nbackground: linear-gradient(180deg, rgba(225,225,225,0) 50%, #00bb00 50%);\r\n}\r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n

    that's it, the preview should look like this\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nCss Wavy lines\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWith just a single div you can create a Wavy effect with pure css\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n // HTML code\r\n <div class=\"wavy-line\"><div>\r\n\r\n// Css\r\n\r\n.wavy-line {\r\n    position: relative;\r\n    width: 100vw;\r\n    height: 50px;\r\n}\r\n.wavy-line::before, .line::after {\r\n    content: \"\";\r\n    display: block;\r\n    position: absolute;\r\n    width: 100vw; /*same width as container*/\r\n    height: 26px;\r\n}\r\n.wavy-line::after {\r\n    background: linear-gradient(45deg, transparent, transparent 49%, green 49%, transparent 51%);\r\n}\r\n.wavy-line::before {\r\n    background: linear-gradient(-45deg, transparent, transparent 49%, green 49%, transparent 51%);\r\n}\r\n.wavy-line::before, .line::after {\r\n    background-size: 50px 50px;\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nThere you go, and the preview should look like the one below\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nAnimate line on hover\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nAnother cool thing you can do with css lines is animating them....\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n // HTML code\r\n     <a href=\"#0\" class=\"line-animate\">\r\n        hover me\r\n    </a>\r\n\r\n// Css\r\n\r\n.line-animate {\r\n    display: inline-block;\r\n    text-decoration: none;\r\n    font-size: 26px;\r\n    color: green;\r\n    position: relative;\r\n}\r\n.line-animate:hover.line-animate::after {\r\n    content: \"\";\r\n    display: block;\r\n    width: 100%;\r\n    height: 4px;\r\n    position: absolute;\r\n    top: 100%;\r\n    background-image: linear-gradient(#ddd,#ddd);\r\n    background-size: 100% .1em;\r\n    animation: animate .5s linear;\r\n\r\n}\r\n\r\n@keyframes animate {\r\n    0% {\r\n        width: 0;\r\n    }\r\n    50% {\r\n        width: 100%;\r\n    }\r\n    0% {\r\n        width: 0;\r\n    }\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n \r\n hover me\r\n \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
