to my personal blog and online journal","author":"Spruce","summary":"An introduction plus a welcome to my personal blog and online journal\n","preview":"img/preview.mp4","page":{"date":"2020-12-18T00:00:00.000Z","inputPath":"./src/blog/welcome-to-my-personal-blog/index.md","fileSlug":"welcome-to-my-personal-blog","filePathStem":"/blog/welcome-to-my-personal-blog/index","url":"/blog/welcome-to-my-personal-blog/","outputPath":"public/blog/welcome-to-my-personal-blog/index.html"}},"computedData":{"computed":{"page":{}},"templateStringKeyLookup":{"page.url":true,"page.outputPath":true},"computedKeys":{},"declaredDependencies":{"page.url":[],"page.outputPath":[]},"queue":{"graph":{"nodes":{},"outgoingEdges":{},"incomingEdges":{}}}}},"inputPath":"./src/blog/welcome-to-my-personal-blog/index.md","fileSlug":"welcome-to-my-personal-blog","filePathStem":"/blog/welcome-to-my-personal-blog/index","data":{"layout":"layouts/posts.liquid","date":"2020-12-18T00:00:00.000Z","title":"Welcome to my personal blog and online journal","author":"Spruce","summary":"An introduction plus a welcome to my personal blog and online journal\n","preview":"img/preview.mp4","collections":{"all":[null,{"template":{"inputPath":"./src/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.md","inputDir":"src","parsed":{"root":"","dir":"./src/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"./src/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone","stem":"index","path":"./src/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\src\\blog\\create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"extraOutputSubdirectory":"","outputDir":"public","linters":[],"transforms":[],"plugins":{},"paginationData":{},"isVerbose":true,"isDryRun":false,"writeCount":0,"skippedCount":0,"wrapWithLayouts":true,"fileSlug":{"inputPath":"blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.md","cleanInputPath":"blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.md","dirs":["blog","create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone"],"parsed":{"root":"","dir":"blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone","stem":"index","path":"blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\blog\\create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"filenameNoExt":"index"},"fileSlugStr":"create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone","filePathStem":"/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index","_templateRender":{"engineNameOrPath":"./src/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.md","inputDir":"src","includesDir":"src/_includes","parseMarkdownWith":"liquid","parseHtmlWith":"liquid","_engineName":"md","useMarkdown":true},"inputContent":"---\r\ndate: 2020-12-20\r\ntitle: Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone With Jekyll On Github\r\nauthor: Spruce\r\nauthor_link: spruce.emma\r\nsummary: >\r\n Have you ever wanted to own your own blog? Well if you have, this series will get you started immediately\r\npreview: img/preview.png\r\nsharing:\r\n twitter: Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone With Jekyll On Github\r\n facebook: Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone With Jekyll On Github\r\n---\r\n\r\n

    \r\nWelcome to the series \"How to create a blog on your mobile phone with Jekyll on Github\"\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nYep i said it... You can create a free blog from your mobile phone, so get ready to start your journey as a blogger... \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\na lot of people do ask:\r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nHow can i create a website with my phone?\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nCan we blog from mobile?\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nwhat is the best phone for blogging?\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nYes, Yes and Yes you can create a website with your phone, you can blog from your mobile phone and you dont need a special phone for blogging. \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWhat is moblie bloging?\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nMobile blogging is a method of publishing to a website or blog from a mobile phone or other handheld device. A mobile blogs help habitual bloggers to post write-ups directly from their phones even when on the move.\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWell i hope from the defination you understand what a mobile blog is and what we are trying to do here...\r\nwell as you might have guessed we are trying to create a free website or blog which you can update, design and post to directly from your mobile phone. \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nRequirements:\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nHTML\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nCSS\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nJAVASCRIPT (optional)\r\n
      4. \r\n
    4. \r\nGithub account\r\n
      5. \r\n
    5. \r\nSPCK Editor\r\n
      6. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nBefore you beging this series with me, it is required you just have a basic knowledge of Html, Css, and javascript is optional for now, well if you dont have a basic knowledge and you are just hearing about all this for the first time, dont worry this articles Getting Started With The Web , Structuring the web with HTML should basically get you started. \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nOther requirements are the github account: Github is a subsidiary of Microsoft which provides hosting for software development and version control using Git.
    \r\nNow dont worry about the defination, you probably will never need it anyway. All you need is to Create an Account(which is totally free), head over to Github.com and create an account. \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThen Spck Editor, this is just a really cool code editor and js sandbox, this is the closest thing that is close to vscode on a mobile phone.
    \r\nHead over to play store search for \"Spck editor\" and install it. This editor is what we'll use to write to our blog...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n Note: It is required that you create a github account, and have downloaded and installed the app before you continue.
    \r\n Please don't use Opera Mini, use a modern browser like Chrome or Firefox\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nGetting Started\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nNow make sure you have created your Github account by signing up
    \r\nNow Click below link (Open in a different tab)
    \r\nJekyll now starter theme\r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n Now its time to Fork the starter theme
    \r\n click on the Forks icon \r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nThe page would reload and you would see a desktop view of the page, just look at the right side of the page at the header (top of the webpage) and click on fork\r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nAfter doing that the next page you are going to see would ask you to change your Forked theme name
    \r\nNow change the name of the website to: \"github-username.github.io\"\r\n

    \r\n \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNow its time to create a github token for the spck editor app you downloaded earlier...
    \r\nclick on the dropdown menu at the top of the page\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\n

      \r\n from the dropdown: \r\n
      \r\n
    1. Click on settings
      2. \r\n
    2. developer settings
      3. \r\n
    3. personal access tokens
      4. \r\n
    4. Generate New Token
      5. \r\n
    5. You may be asked for password, just enter your github password and continue
      6. \r\n\r\n
        \r\n
      1. Give it a note: Spck editor
        2. \r\n
      2. click on the repo box (select everything under it)
        3. \r\n
      3. Scroll select write:packages and admin:org
        4. \r\n
      4. Click \"Generate Token\"
        5. \r\n
      \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nAfter you have generated your token ensure you copy it to your phone clipboard because you wont see again unless you re-generate it.\r\n

    \r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nIf you have followed this guide perfectly, you are just a few steps away from your newly phone managed blog or website.\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nMoving on, Do you remember the \"Spck editor\" you downloaded earlier? Yep i guess you do
    \r\nNow open it up
    \r\nAnd you should see something that looks like this image below\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nNext step is to look at the PROJECTS tab
    \r\nClick on the third icon (The fork icon)\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nWhen you click on fork icon
    \r\nSelect credentials
    \r\nSet up your Credentials as follows:
    \r\nname: Github username
    \r\npassword/token: The token you Generated earlier (The one you copied)
    \r\nemail: for email (The one used in opening your github account)
    \r\nThen just Click on \"OK\"\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nNow its time to clone your website to your mobile phone
    \r\nClick on the Fork icon again
    \r\nJust enter your Url like this

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n url: https://github.com/github-username/github-username.github.io \r\n
    \r\njust change \"github-username\" to your own github username
    \r\nthen just Click on \"OK\"
    \r\nand wait for your website to clone (Speed depends on your internet connection, mine took a few seconds)\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nYep, You guessed it, that's all. If you followed the steps correctly then i congratulate you(yeah you can feel proud). You have created a free website, and you can now manage, edit and design it on your mob ile phone. \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nTo view your website
    \r\ngo to your browser
    \r\ntype in your website url
    \r\n\"github-username.github.io\"
    \r\nin my case \"sprucestatic.github.io\"\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nHonestly you should be proud now. Welcome to the bloggers and website owners association of the world.
    \r\nNow you can go and tell your family members, friends, share it on facebook and twitter, about your new website... \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThough not really much now, Before the end of this series you will learn how to create and update a fully functional blog from your mobile phone...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n Next step is Customizing your new website, and introducing you to GIT on your mobile phone... Thanks for reading.\r\n

    \r\n \r\n
    \r\nNext part of this series\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 2\r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n","frontMatter":{"content":"\r\n

    \r\nWelcome to the series \"How to create a blog on your mobile phone with Jekyll on Github\"\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nYep i said it... You can create a free blog from your mobile phone, so get ready to start your journey as a blogger... \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\na lot of people do ask:\r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nHow can i create a website with my phone?\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nCan we blog from mobile?\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nwhat is the best phone for blogging?\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nYes, Yes and Yes you can create a website with your phone, you can blog from your mobile phone and you dont need a special phone for blogging. \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWhat is moblie bloging?\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nMobile blogging is a method of publishing to a website or blog from a mobile phone or other handheld device. A mobile blogs help habitual bloggers to post write-ups directly from their phones even when on the move.\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWell i hope from the defination you understand what a mobile blog is and what we are trying to do here...\r\nwell as you might have guessed we are trying to create a free website or blog which you can update, design and post to directly from your mobile phone. \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nRequirements:\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nHTML\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nCSS\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nJAVASCRIPT (optional)\r\n
      4. \r\n
    4. \r\nGithub account\r\n
      5. \r\n
    5. \r\nSPCK Editor\r\n
      6. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nBefore you beging this series with me, it is required you just have a basic knowledge of Html, Css, and javascript is optional for now, well if you dont have a basic knowledge and you are just hearing about all this for the first time, dont worry this articles Getting Started With The Web , Structuring the web with HTML should basically get you started. \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nOther requirements are the github account: Github is a subsidiary of Microsoft which provides hosting for software development and version control using Git.
    \r\nNow dont worry about the defination, you probably will never need it anyway. All you need is to Create an Account(which is totally free), head over to Github.com and create an account. \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThen Spck Editor, this is just a really cool code editor and js sandbox, this is the closest thing that is close to vscode on a mobile phone.
    \r\nHead over to play store search for \"Spck editor\" and install it. This editor is what we'll use to write to our blog...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n Note: It is required that you create a github account, and have downloaded and installed the app before you continue.
    \r\n Please don't use Opera Mini, use a modern browser like Chrome or Firefox\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nGetting Started\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nNow make sure you have created your Github account by signing up
    \r\nNow Click below link (Open in a different tab)
    \r\nJekyll now starter theme\r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n Now its time to Fork the starter theme
    \r\n click on the Forks icon \r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nThe page would reload and you would see a desktop view of the page, just look at the right side of the page at the header (top of the webpage) and click on fork\r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nAfter doing that the next page you are going to see would ask you to change your Forked theme name
    \r\nNow change the name of the website to: \"github-username.github.io\"\r\n

    \r\n \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNow its time to create a github token for the spck editor app you downloaded earlier...
    \r\nclick on the dropdown menu at the top of the page\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\n

      \r\n from the dropdown: \r\n
      \r\n
    1. Click on settings
      2. \r\n
    2. developer settings
      3. \r\n
    3. personal access tokens
      4. \r\n
    4. Generate New Token
      5. \r\n
    5. You may be asked for password, just enter your github password and continue
      6. \r\n\r\n
        \r\n
      1. Give it a note: Spck editor
        2. \r\n
      2. click on the repo box (select everything under it)
        3. \r\n
      3. Scroll select write:packages and admin:org
        4. \r\n
      4. Click \"Generate Token\"
        5. \r\n
      \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nAfter you have generated your token ensure you copy it to your phone clipboard because you wont see again unless you re-generate it.\r\n

    \r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nIf you have followed this guide perfectly, you are just a few steps away from your newly phone managed blog or website.\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nMoving on, Do you remember the \"Spck editor\" you downloaded earlier? Yep i guess you do
    \r\nNow open it up
    \r\nAnd you should see something that looks like this image below\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nNext step is to look at the PROJECTS tab
    \r\nClick on the third icon (The fork icon)\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nWhen you click on fork icon
    \r\nSelect credentials
    \r\nSet up your Credentials as follows:
    \r\nname: Github username
    \r\npassword/token: The token you Generated earlier (The one you copied)
    \r\nemail: for email (The one used in opening your github account)
    \r\nThen just Click on \"OK\"\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nNow its time to clone your website to your mobile phone
    \r\nClick on the Fork icon again
    \r\nJust enter your Url like this

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n url: https://github.com/github-username/github-username.github.io \r\n
    \r\njust change \"github-username\" to your own github username
    \r\nthen just Click on \"OK\"
    \r\nand wait for your website to clone (Speed depends on your internet connection, mine took a few seconds)\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nYep, You guessed it, that's all. If you followed the steps correctly then i congratulate you(yeah you can feel proud). You have created a free website, and you can now manage, edit and design it on your mob ile phone. \r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nTo view your website
    \r\ngo to your browser
    \r\ntype in your website url
    \r\n\"github-username.github.io\"
    \r\nin my case \"sprucestatic.github.io\"\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nHonestly you should be proud now. Welcome to the bloggers and website owners association of the world.
    \r\nNow you can go and tell your family members, friends, share it on facebook and twitter, about your new website... \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThough not really much now, Before the end of this series you will learn how to create and update a fully functional blog from your mobile phone...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n Next step is Customizing your new website, and introducing you to GIT on your mobile phone... Thanks for reading.\r\n

    \r\n \r\n
    \r\nNext part of this series\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 2\r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n","data":{"date":"2020-12-20T00:00:00.000Z","title":"Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone With Jekyll On Github","author":"Spruce","author_link":"spruce.emma","summary":"Have you ever wanted to own your own blog? Well if you have, this series will get you started immediately\n","preview":"img/preview.png","sharing":{"twitter":"Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone With Jekyll On Github","facebook":"Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone With Jekyll On Github"}},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""},"_layoutKey":"layouts/posts.liquid","dataCache":{"layout":"layouts/posts.liquid","tags":["norm"],"date":"2020-12-20T00:00:00.000Z","title":"Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone With Jekyll On Github","author":"Spruce","author_link":"spruce.emma","summary":"Have you ever wanted to own your own blog? Well if you have, this series will get you started immediately\n","preview":"img/preview.png","page":{"date":"2020-12-20T00:00:00.000Z","inputPath":"./src/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.md","fileSlug":"create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone","filePathStem":"/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index","url":"/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/","outputPath":"public/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.html"}},"computedData":{"computed":{"page":{}},"templateStringKeyLookup":{"page.url":true,"page.outputPath":true},"computedKeys":{},"declaredDependencies":{"page.url":[],"page.outputPath":[]},"queue":{"graph":{"nodes":{},"outgoingEdges":{},"incomingEdges":{}}}}},"inputPath":"./src/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.md","fileSlug":"create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone","filePathStem":"/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index","data":{"layout":"layouts/posts.liquid","date":"2020-12-20T00:00:00.000Z","title":"Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone With Jekyll On Github","author":"Spruce","author_link":"spruce.emma","summary":"Have you ever wanted to own your own blog? Well if you have, this series will get you started immediately\n","preview":"img/preview.png"},"date":"2020-12-20T00:00:00.000Z","outputPath":"public/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/index.html","url":"/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone/","templateContent":"

    \nWelcome to the series \"How to create a blog on your mobile phone with Jekyll on Github\"\n

    \n

    \nYep i said it... You can create a free blog from your mobile phone, so get ready to start your journey as a blogger... \n

    \n

    \na lot of people do ask:\n

      \n
    1. \nHow can i create a website with my phone?\n
      2. \n
    2. \nCan we blog from mobile?\n
      3. \n
    3. \nwhat is the best phone for blogging?\n
      4. \n
    \n

    \n

    \nYes, Yes and Yes you can create a website with your phone, you can blog from your mobile phone and you dont need a special phone for blogging. \n

    \n

    \nWhat is moblie bloging?\n

    \n

    \nMobile blogging is a method of publishing to a website or blog from a mobile phone or other handheld device. A mobile blogs help habitual bloggers to post write-ups directly from their phones even when on the move.\n

    \n

    \nWell i hope from the defination you understand what a mobile blog is and what we are trying to do here...\nwell as you might have guessed we are trying to create a free website or blog which you can update, design and post to directly from your mobile phone. \n

    \n

    \nRequirements:\n

    \n
      \n
    1. \nHTML\n
      2. \n
    2. \nCSS\n
      3. \n
    3. \nJAVASCRIPT (optional)\n
      4. \n
    4. \nGithub account\n
      5. \n
    5. \nSPCK Editor\n
      6. \n
    \n

    \nBefore you beging this series with me, it is required you just have a basic knowledge of Html, Css, and javascript is optional for now, well if you dont have a basic knowledge and you are just hearing about all this for the first time, dont worry this articles Getting Started With The Web , Structuring the web with HTML should basically get you started. \n

    \n

    \nOther requirements are the github account: Github is a subsidiary of Microsoft which provides hosting for software development and version control using Git.
    \nNow dont worry about the defination, you probably will never need it anyway. All you need is to Create an Account(which is totally free), head over to Github.com and create an account. \n

    \n

    \nThen Spck Editor, this is just a really cool code editor and js sandbox, this is the closest thing that is close to vscode on a mobile phone.
    \nHead over to play store search for \"Spck editor\" and install it. This editor is what we'll use to write to our blog...\n

    \n
    \n
    \n Note: It is required that you create a github account, and have downloaded and installed the app before you continue.
    \n Please don't use Opera Mini, use a modern browser like Chrome or Firefox\n
    \n
    \n

    \nGetting Started\n

    \n

    \nNow make sure you have created your Github account by signing up
    \nNow Click below link (Open in a different tab)
    \nJekyll now starter theme\n\n

    \n\n

    \n Now its time to Fork the starter theme
    \n click on the Forks icon \n

    \n \n

    \nThe page would reload and you would see a desktop view of the page, just look at the right side of the page at the header (top of the webpage) and click on fork\n

    \n\n

    \nAfter doing that the next page you are going to see would ask you to change your Forked theme name
    \nNow change the name of the website to: \"github-username.github.io\"\n

    \n \n \n

    \nNow its time to create a github token for the spck editor app you downloaded earlier...
    \nclick on the dropdown menu at the top of the page\n

    \n \n

    \n

      \n from the dropdown: \n
      \n
    1. Click on settings
      2. \n
    2. developer settings
      3. \n
    3. personal access tokens
      4. \n
    4. Generate New Token
      5. \n
    5. You may be asked for password, just enter your github password and continue
      6. \n
        \n
      1. Give it a note: Spck editor
        2. \n
      2. click on the repo box (select everything under it)
        3. \n
      3. Scroll select write:packages and admin:org
        4. \n
      4. Click \"Generate Token\"
        5. \n
      \n
    \n

    \n \n

    \nAfter you have generated your token ensure you copy it to your phone clipboard because you wont see again unless you re-generate it.\n

    \n \n

    \nIf you have followed this guide perfectly, you are just a few steps away from your newly phone managed blog or website.\n

    \n

    \nMoving on, Do you remember the \"Spck editor\" you downloaded earlier? Yep i guess you do
    \nNow open it up
    \nAnd you should see something that looks like this image below\n

    \n \n

    \nNext step is to look at the PROJECTS tab
    \nClick on the third icon (The fork icon)\n

    \n \n

    \nWhen you click on fork icon
    \nSelect credentials
    \nSet up your Credentials as follows:
    \nname: Github username
    \npassword/token: The token you Generated earlier (The one you copied)
    \nemail: for email (The one used in opening your github account)
    \nThen just Click on \"OK\"\n

    \n

    \nNow its time to clone your website to your mobile phone
    \nClick on the Fork icon again
    \nJust enter your Url like this

    \n\n

    \n url: https://github.com/github-username/github-username.github.io \n
    \njust change \"github-username\" to your own github username
    \nthen just Click on \"OK\"
    \nand wait for your website to clone (Speed depends on your internet connection, mine took a few seconds)\n

    \n \n

    \nYep, You guessed it, that's all. If you followed the steps correctly then i congratulate you(yeah you can feel proud). You have created a free website, and you can now manage, edit and design it on your mob ile phone. \n

    \n

    \nTo view your website
    \ngo to your browser
    \ntype in your website url
    \n\"github-username.github.io\"
    \nin my case \"sprucestatic.github.io\"\n

    \n \n

    \nHonestly you should be proud now. Welcome to the bloggers and website owners association of the world.
    \nNow you can go and tell your family members, friends, share it on facebook and twitter, about your new website... \n

    \n

    \nThough not really much now, Before the end of this series you will learn how to create and update a fully functional blog from your mobile phone...\n

    \n

    \n Next step is Customizing your new website, and introducing you to GIT on your mobile phone... Thanks for reading.\n

    \nNow open it up

    \nSelect credentials

2020-12-21\r\ntitle: Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone Part 2 \r\nauthor: Spruce\r\nsummary: >\r\n Welcome to the second part of \"how to create a blog on your mobile phone with jekyll on github\", In this part you will learn hot to perform \"GIT\" actions with your phone. \r\npreview: img/preview.png\r\nsharing:\r\n twitter: Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone Part 2\r\n facebook: Create A Blog On Your Mobile Phone Part 2\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n

    \r\nHello dear reader and welcome to the second part of this web series on how to create a website or blog right from your mobile phone. \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nQuick Recap\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nLike i said this is the second part of this series, incase you missed the first part you can always go back and read it here:

    \r\nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1.
    \r\nTalking about reading the other article, You should really read that article up as this one is just building on what we learned in the orther article
    \r\n

      \r\nWe learn't a few and very essentials things though:\r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nconcept of mobile blogging\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nhow to create a free website/blog\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nhow to clone your website/blog to your mobile phone\r\n
      4. \r\n
    4. \r\nand quit a all lot of other things\r\n
      5. \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\nDon't just take my word for it, you should read it up yourself.\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nRequirements\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nBefore you continue on this tutorial you should have at least a basic knowledge of the things listed below\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nHTML\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nHow the web works (refer to part 1)\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nYep thats all you will be needing for this part of the series...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWelcome to jekyll\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nIf you are the curious type like me, you would have asked yourself, what is JEKYLL\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWhat really is Jekyll?\r\n

    \r\n\r\nJekyll is a static site generator. it takes text written in your favorite markup language and uses layouts to create a static website. You can tweak the sites's look and feel, URLs, the data displayed on the page and more \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nFrom the defination you get the idea... Jekyll is just plain html text that are converted to static website's.
    \r\nWell static is the opposite of Dynamic, think of jekyll as the opposite of Dynamic websites built on WordPress and other dynamic websites...
    \r\nof course being static is one of the features i like about jekyll, being static means your pages load super fast, no third party content(You own your contents and codes), and easy set up and customization, like you create a website with just Html, Css and js, Jeez how super fast is that...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nIn addition to all its other cools features and plugins, it also uses the Shopify Liquid:
    \r\nLquid is an open-source template language created by shopify and written in Ruby.

    \r\nDid i also mention that jekyll and github are completely free?
    \r\nYep they sure are.\r\n\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nResources to learn jekyll\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nyou can learn all about jekyll and liquid from the below links\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\njekyll official documentation\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nliquid official documentation\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nIntro to git \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nWhat is git?

    \r\nGit is a distributed version-control system for tracking changes in any set of files... and so on \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nBasically git is just meant and used to commit, pull and push changes to your remote repository\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\na\r\nA lot of terminologies used here, dont worry about that, you will soon see them in action very soon, but before then let me introduce you to what they are and how they are connected to creating a site on your mobile phone\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nCOMMIT: this command is used to save your changes to your local repository (the site you cloned to your mobile phone in the part 1 of this series)\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nPUSH: this command is used to push(as the name implies) all the files you have commited to your remote repository\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nREMOTE REPO: This is a common repository that all team members use to exchange their changes. This repository is stored on a code hosting service like Github(That's where github comes in)\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\nConncecting the dots...\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nYou may be wondering, how does this have to do with blogging from mobile phone...
    \r\nwell from the explanations above, you only need two things\r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nRemote Repository\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nA place to run Git commands from\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nyou already have a remote repo, so you shouldn't worry about that, what i will introduce to you is how you can execute git commands on your mobile phone\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nI guess we are done talking...\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nToo much talk and explanations (I really hope you get the idea), now lets stop talking and start showing how things work\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nGo ahead and lunch your spck editor, [The one you downloaded on the previous post]\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNow its time to upload your own contents

    \r\nScroll down to the images folder and select it\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nClick on the three dots(menu of the image folder),and click on Upload File\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nNow upload a loving photo of your self, or your website logo..
    \r\nNow its time to edit the config file and customize the site to display your own info\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNow close your image folder and look for and open the file called
    \r\n_config.yml
    \r\nwhen you open it, you should see something like this below\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nbasically anything you edit here affects your site drastically, so be careful of what you touch in here\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFirst thing you should change is name, in your config file change your name\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\nname: your name\r\n#Change it to the name you want to use\r\n#name: Spruce\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nChange the description too\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\ndescription: web developer from somewhere\r\n#Change it to anything you want, just dont make it too look (seo issues)\r\n#description: web developer based in Edo, Nigeria\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nDo you remember the image you uploaded? yep you do, its time to use it. From the Getting Started With The Web you read in the first part of this series i assume you now know how the web work...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\navatar: https://....\r\n#Change it to the file you uploaded earlier\r\navatar: /images/spruce.jpg #in my case\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nEdit your footer links, add your social media liks to the footer links\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\nfooter-links:\r\n  dribble: dribble username\r\n  email:\r\n  facebook:\r\n  ..... etc\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nChange your url to your site url\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\nurl: github-username.github.io\r\n#where github username is changed to your username\r\nurl: sprucestatic.github.io #in my case \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n Note: Leave the baseurl feed empty if your site is \"github-username.github.io\", but if your site is \"github-username/static-site-name\" add \"/static-site-name\" to the baseurl
    \r\n but if you have followed this series from the beginning please leave baseurl empty...\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nNow its time to use the Git commands we explained before now
    \r\nin the spck editor

    \r\nClick on the last fork icon at the bottom of the editor\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nOnce you have click on the fork icon, you should see something that looks like the one below \r\n

    \r\n\r\n \r\n

    \r\nthe next steps are easy\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nClick on Commit All\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nEnter commit Message\r\n
      3. \r\n

      \r\nYou can enter anything in your commit message, but that dosen't mean you should just write a bunch of anything you think of, a commit message should briefly explain the changes you made to your project.\r\n

      \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nRemember from our defination of commit, it just save the changes to your local computer, in our case your mobile phone, that is the changes wont reflect on the web just yet, Now that is where GIT PUSH comes in the picture... Push as the name implies pushes your saved commit to your remote repo (the one hosted on github) so that people can view it on the web. \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nAs you might have noticed, editing, uploading and committing to your cloned project dosen't require any data Connection. But when pushing your changes, you need a data connection, So go ahead and switch on your data connection and follow the below steps\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\nTo push your changes follow this steps:

      \r\n
    1. \r\nClick on the last fork icon again\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nClick on push\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nClick Ok\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nBoom and there you go, your websites should be live with your changes on the web in a minute...
    \r\nGo ahead and preview your website\r\n

    \r\n\r\n \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWell thats the end of this part of the series... Next stop is Blogging, Thanks for reading...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nPrevious parts of this series\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1\r\n

    \r\n","frontMatter":{"content":"\r\n

    \r\nHello dear reader and welcome to the second part of this web series on how to create a website or blog right from your mobile phone. \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nQuick Recap\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nLike i said this is the second part of this series, incase you missed the first part you can always go back and read it here:

    \r\nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1.
    \r\nTalking about reading the other article, You should really read that article up as this one is just building on what we learned in the orther article
    \r\n

      \r\nWe learn't a few and very essentials things though:\r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nconcept of mobile blogging\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nhow to create a free website/blog\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nhow to clone your website/blog to your mobile phone\r\n
      4. \r\n
    4. \r\nand quit a all lot of other things\r\n
      5. \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\nDon't just take my word for it, you should read it up yourself.\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nRequirements\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nBefore you continue on this tutorial you should have at least a basic knowledge of the things listed below\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nHTML\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nHow the web works (refer to part 1)\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nYep thats all you will be needing for this part of the series...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWelcome to jekyll\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nIf you are the curious type like me, you would have asked yourself, what is JEKYLL\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWhat really is Jekyll?\r\n

    \r\n\r\nJekyll is a static site generator. it takes text written in your favorite markup language and uses layouts to create a static website. You can tweak the sites's look and feel, URLs, the data displayed on the page and more \r\n\r\n\r\n

    \r\nFrom the defination you get the idea... Jekyll is just plain html text that are converted to static website's.
    \r\nWell static is the opposite of Dynamic, think of jekyll as the opposite of Dynamic websites built on WordPress and other dynamic websites...
    \r\nof course being static is one of the features i like about jekyll, being static means your pages load super fast, no third party content(You own your contents and codes), and easy set up and customization, like you create a website with just Html, Css and js, Jeez how super fast is that...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nIn addition to all its other cools features and plugins, it also uses the Shopify Liquid:
    \r\nLquid is an open-source template language created by shopify and written in Ruby.

    \r\nDid i also mention that jekyll and github are completely free?
    \r\nYep they sure are.\r\n\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nResources to learn jekyll\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nyou can learn all about jekyll and liquid from the below links\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\njekyll official documentation\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nliquid official documentation\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nIntro to git \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nWhat is git?

    \r\nGit is a distributed version-control system for tracking changes in any set of files... and so on \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nBasically git is just meant and used to commit, pull and push changes to your remote repository\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\na\r\nA lot of terminologies used here, dont worry about that, you will soon see them in action very soon, but before then let me introduce you to what they are and how they are connected to creating a site on your mobile phone\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nCOMMIT: this command is used to save your changes to your local repository (the site you cloned to your mobile phone in the part 1 of this series)\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nPUSH: this command is used to push(as the name implies) all the files you have commited to your remote repository\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nREMOTE REPO: This is a common repository that all team members use to exchange their changes. This repository is stored on a code hosting service like Github(That's where github comes in)\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n
    \r\nConncecting the dots...\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nYou may be wondering, how does this have to do with blogging from mobile phone...
    \r\nwell from the explanations above, you only need two things\r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nRemote Repository\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nA place to run Git commands from\r\n
      3. \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nyou already have a remote repo, so you shouldn't worry about that, what i will introduce to you is how you can execute git commands on your mobile phone\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nI guess we are done talking...\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nToo much talk and explanations (I really hope you get the idea), now lets stop talking and start showing how things work\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nGo ahead and lunch your spck editor, [The one you downloaded on the previous post]\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNow its time to upload your own contents

    \r\nScroll down to the images folder and select it\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nClick on the three dots(menu of the image folder),and click on Upload File\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nNow upload a loving photo of your self, or your website logo..
    \r\nNow its time to edit the config file and customize the site to display your own info\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNow close your image folder and look for and open the file called
    \r\n_config.yml
    \r\nwhen you open it, you should see something like this below\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nbasically anything you edit here affects your site drastically, so be careful of what you touch in here\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFirst thing you should change is name, in your config file change your name\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\nname: your name\r\n#Change it to the name you want to use\r\n#name: Spruce\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nChange the description too\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\ndescription: web developer from somewhere\r\n#Change it to anything you want, just dont make it too look (seo issues)\r\n#description: web developer based in Edo, Nigeria\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nDo you remember the image you uploaded? yep you do, its time to use it. From the Getting Started With The Web you read in the first part of this series i assume you now know how the web work...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\navatar: https://....\r\n#Change it to the file you uploaded earlier\r\navatar: /images/spruce.jpg #in my case\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nEdit your footer links, add your social media liks to the footer links\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\nfooter-links:\r\n  dribble: dribble username\r\n  email:\r\n  facebook:\r\n  ..... etc\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nChange your url to your site url\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\nurl: github-username.github.io\r\n#where github username is changed to your username\r\nurl: sprucestatic.github.io #in my case \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n Note: Leave the baseurl feed empty if your site is \"github-username.github.io\", but if your site is \"github-username/static-site-name\" add \"/static-site-name\" to the baseurl
    \r\n but if you have followed this series from the beginning please leave baseurl empty...\r\n
    \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nNow its time to use the Git commands we explained before now
    \r\nin the spck editor

    \r\nClick on the last fork icon at the bottom of the editor\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nOnce you have click on the fork icon, you should see something that looks like the one below \r\n

    \r\n\r\n \r\n

    \r\nthe next steps are easy\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nClick on Commit All\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nEnter commit Message\r\n
      3. \r\n

      \r\nYou can enter anything in your commit message, but that dosen't mean you should just write a bunch of anything you think of, a commit message should briefly explain the changes you made to your project.\r\n

      \r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nRemember from our defination of commit, it just save the changes to your local computer, in our case your mobile phone, that is the changes wont reflect on the web just yet, Now that is where GIT PUSH comes in the picture... Push as the name implies pushes your saved commit to your remote repo (the one hosted on github) so that people can view it on the web. \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nAs you might have noticed, editing, uploading and committing to your cloned project dosen't require any data Connection. But when pushing your changes, you need a data connection, So go ahead and switch on your data connection and follow the below steps\r\n

    \r\n
      \r\nTo push your changes follow this steps:

      \r\n
    1. \r\nClick on the last fork icon again\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nClick on push\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nClick Ok\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nBoom and there you go, your websites should be live with your changes on the web in a minute...
    \r\nGo ahead and preview your website\r\n

    \r\n\r\n \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWell thats the end of this part of the series... Next stop is Blogging, Thanks for reading...\r\n

      3. \n

      \n

    \nRemember from our defination of commit, it just save the changes to your local computer, in our case your mobile phone, that is the changes wont reflect on the web just yet, Now that is where GIT PUSH comes in the picture...       \n
    1. \nClick on the last fork icon again\n
      2. \n

      3. \n

      4. \n

    \nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1\n

    \n","_templateContent":"

    \nHello dear reader and welcome to the second part of this web series on how to create a website or blog right from your mobile phone. \n

    \n

    \nQuick Recap\n

    \n

    \nLike i said this is the second part of this series, incase you missed the first part you can always go back and read it here:

    \nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1.
    \nTalking about reading the other article, You should really read that article up as this one is just building on what we learned in the orther article
    \n

      \nWe learn't a few and very essentials things though:\n

      \n
    1. \nconcept of mobile blogging\n
      2. \n
    2. \nhow to create a free website/blog\n
      3. \n
    3. \nhow to clone your website/blog to your mobile phone\n
      4. \n
    4. \nand quit a all lot of other things\n
      5. \n
    \n
    \nDon't just take my word for it, you should read it up yourself.\n

    \n

    \nRequirements\n

    \n

    \nBefore you continue on this tutorial you should have at least a basic knowledge of the things listed below\n

    \n
      \n
    1. \nHTML\n
      2. \n
    2. \nHow the web works (refer to part 1)\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \nYep thats all you will be needing for this part of the series...\n

    \n

    \nWelcome to jekyll\n

    \n

    \nIf you are the curious type like me, you would have asked yourself, what is JEKYLL\n

    \n

    \nWhat really is Jekyll?\n

    \n\nJekyll is a static site generator. it takes text written in your favorite markup language and uses layouts to create a static website. You can tweak the sites's look and feel, URLs, the data displayed on the page and more \n\n

    \nFrom the defination you get the idea... Jekyll is just plain html text that are converted to static website's.
    \nWell static is the opposite of Dynamic, think of jekyll as the opposite of Dynamic websites built on WordPress and other dynamic websites...
    \nof course being static is one of the features i like about jekyll, being static means your pages load super fast, no third party content(You own your contents and codes), and easy set up and customization, like you create a website with just Html, Css and js, Jeez how super fast is that...\n

    \n

    \nIn addition to all its other cools features and plugins, it also uses the Shopify Liquid:
    \nLquid is an open-source template language created by shopify and written in Ruby.

    \nDid i also mention that jekyll and github are completely free?
    \nYep they sure are.\n

    \n
    \nResources to learn jekyll\n
    \n

    \nyou can learn all about jekyll and liquid from the below links\n

    \n
      \n
    1. \njekyll official documentation\n
      2. \n
    2. \nliquid official documentation\n
      3. \n
    \n
    \nIntro to git \n
    \n

    \nWhat is git?

    \nGit is a distributed version-control system for tracking changes in any set of files... and so on \n

    \n

    \nBasically git is just meant and used to commit, pull and push changes to your remote repository\n

    \n

    \na\nA lot of terminologies used here, dont worry about that, you will soon see them in action very soon, but before then let me introduce you to what they are and how they are connected to creating a site on your mobile phone\n

    \n
      \n
    1. \nCOMMIT: this command is used to save your changes to your local repository (the site you cloned to your mobile phone in the part 1 of this series)\n
      2. \n
    2. \nPUSH: this command is used to push(as the name implies) all the files you have commited to your remote repository\n
      3. \n
    3. \nREMOTE REPO: This is a common repository that all team members use to exchange their changes. This repository is stored on a code hosting service like Github(That's where github comes in)\n
      4. \n
    \n
    \nConncecting the dots...\n
    \n

    \nYou may be wondering, how does this have to do with blogging from mobile phone...
    \nwell from the explanations above, you only need two things\n

      \n
    1. \nRemote Repository\n
      2. \n
    2. \nA place to run Git commands from\n
      3. \n
    \n

    \n

    \nyou already have a remote repo, so you shouldn't worry about that, what i will introduce to you is how you can execute git commands on your mobile phone\n

    \n
    \nI guess we are done talking...\n
    \n

    \nToo much talk and explanations (I really hope you get the idea), now lets stop talking and start showing how things work\n

    \n

    \nGo ahead and lunch your spck editor, [The one you downloaded on the previous post]\n

    \n\n

    \nNow its time to upload your own contents

    \nScroll down to the images folder and select it\n

    \n \n

    \nClick on the three dots(menu of the image folder),and click on Upload File\n

    \n \n

    \nNow upload a loving photo of your self, or your website logo..
    \nNow its time to edit the config file and customize the site to display your own info\n

    \n

    \nNow close your image folder and look for and open the file called
    \n_config.yml
    \nwhen you open it, you should see something like this below\n

    \n \n

    \nbasically anything you edit here affects your site drastically, so be careful of what you touch in here\n

    \n

    \nFirst thing you should change is name, in your config file change your name\n

    \n 
    \n\nname: your name\n#Change it to the name you want to use\n#name: Spruce\n\n
    \n

    \nChange the description too\n

    \n 
    \n\ndescription: web developer from somewhere\n#Change it to anything you want, just dont make it too look (seo issues)\n#description: web developer based in Edo, Nigeria\n\n
    \n

    \nDo you remember the image you uploaded? yep you do, its time to use it. From the Getting Started With The Web you read in the first part of this series i assume you now know how the web work...\n

    \n 
    \n\navatar: https://....\n#Change it to the file you uploaded earlier\navatar: /images/spruce.jpg #in my case\n\n
    \n

    \nEdit your footer links, add your social media liks to the footer links\n

    \n 
    \n\nfooter-links:\n  dribble: dribble username\n  email:\n  facebook:\n  ..... etc\n\n
    \n

    \nChange your url to your site url\n

    \n 
    \n\nurl: github-username.github.io\n#where github username is changed to your username\nurl: sprucestatic.github.io #in my case \n\n
    \n
    \n
    \n Note: Leave the baseurl feed empty if your site is \"github-username.github.io\", but if your site is \"github-username/static-site-name\" add \"/static-site-name\" to the baseurl
    \n but if you have followed this series from the beginning please leave baseurl empty...\n
    \n
    \n

    \nNow its time to use the Git commands we explained before now
    \nin the spck editor

    \nClick on the last fork icon at the bottom of the editor\n

    \n\n

    \nOnce you have click on the fork icon, you should see something that looks like the one below \n

    \n \n

    \nthe next steps are easy\n

    \n
      \n
    1. \nClick on Commit All\n
      2. \n
    2. \nEnter commit Message\n
      3. \n

      \nYou can enter anything in your commit message, but that dosen't mean you should just write a bunch of anything you think of, a commit message should briefly explain the changes you made to your project.\n

      \n
    \n

    \nRemember from our defination of commit, it just save the changes to your local computer, in our case your mobile phone, that is the changes wont reflect on the web just yet, Now that is where GIT PUSH comes in the picture... Push as the name implies pushes your saved commit to your remote repo (the one hosted on github) so that people can view it on the web. \n

    \n

    \nAs you might have noticed, editing, uploading and committing to your cloned project dosen't require any data Connection. But when pushing your changes, you need a data connection, So go ahead and switch on your data connection and follow the below steps\n

    \n
      \nTo push your changes follow this steps:

      \n
    1. \nClick on the last fork icon again\n
      2. \n
    2. \nClick on push\n
      3. \n
    3. \nClick Ok\n
      4. \n
    \n \n

    \nBoom and there you go, your websites should be live with your changes on the web in a minute...
    \nGo ahead and preview your website\n

    \n \n

    \n

    \n \n

    \nWell thats the end of this part of the series... Next stop is Blogging, Thanks for reading...\n

    \n
    \nPrevious parts of this series\n
    \n

    \nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1\n

    \r\nSad to announce the end of this \"how to create a blog on your mobile phone series\", well i know we have learned a lot of new things in this web series\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nSome things we have learned so far\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    1. \r\nwhat mobile blogging is\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nhow to create a free website on github with jekyll\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\nhow to clone your website to your mobile phone\r\n
      4. \r\n
    4. \r\nhow to run some basic Git Commands in your mobile phone\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nincase you missed the other series, don't worry you can always go back and read them up\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nLink to previous series\r\n

    \r\nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 2\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nNow lets go back to what we are really here for, blogging from your mobile phone\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nWhat is blogging\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n Blogging refers to writing, photography, and other media that is self-published online.\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nSo basically you know what blogging is all about, its a way for a lot of people to express their feelings and share there ideas online.\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nBlogging with jekyll\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nyour blog posts live in a directory called _posts in the root of your site, so basically thats where you will add all your blog posts\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nYour blog file names begin with \"year-month-date-your-title.md\"
    \r\nso when creating your post, always follow the order Year-month-date-title.md \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nfor a detailed on how to write blog posts on jekyll please refer to this jekyll guide below

    \r\nLearn more about jekyll post\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nPublishing your first post\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThe first step is to open your spck editor, The editor you downloaded in the first part of this series, open it and navigate to your _posts folder\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nGo ahead and delete the post found there and create another one with

    \r\nYEAR-MONTH-DAY-TITLE.md format\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nAfter you created the post
    \r\nadd your layout and title like this\r\n

    \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\nNow you can add anything to your blog post, after all you are now a blogger, after you are done with writting your post, just go ahead and commit your changes and then push them online like we learned in our previous post\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nand there you have it, you just created your first post, go ahead and preview your new post online\r\n

    \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n \r\n\r\n

    \n

    \nWhat is blogging\n

    \n

    \n Blogging refers to writing, photography, and other media that is self-published online.\n

    \n

    \nSo basically you know what blogging is all about, its a way for a lot of people to express their feelings and share there ideas online.\n

    \n

    \nBlogging with jekyll\n

    \n

    \nyour blog posts live in a directory called _posts in the root of your site, so basically thats where you will add all your blog posts\n

    \n

    \nYour blog file names begin with \"year-month-date-your-title.md\"
    \nso when creating your post, always follow the order Year-month-date-title.md \n

    \n

    \nfor a detailed on how to write blog posts on jekyll please refer to this jekyll guide below

    \nLearn more about jekyll post\n

    \n

    \nPublishing your first post\n

    \n

    \nThe first step is to open your spck editor, The editor you downloaded in the first part of this series, open it and navigate to your _posts folder\n

    \n \n

    \nGo ahead and delete the post found there and create another one with

    \nYEAR-MONTH-DAY-TITLE.md format\n

    \n \n

    \nAfter you created the post
    \nadd your layout and title like this\n

    \n \n

    \nNow you can add anything to your blog post, after all you are now a blogger, after you are done with writting your post, just go ahead and commit your changes and then push them online like we learned in our previous post\n

    \nand there you have it, you just created your first post, go ahead and preview your new post online\n

    \nSad to announce the end of this \"how to create a blog on your mobile phone series\", well i know we have learned a lot of new things in this web series\n

    \n
    \nSome things we have learned so far\n
    \n
      \n
    1. \nwhat mobile blogging is\n
      2. \n
    2. \nhow to create a free website on github with jekyll\n
      3. \n
    3. \nhow to clone your website to your mobile phone\n
      4. \n
    4. \nhow to run some basic Git Commands in your mobile phone\n
      5. \n
    5. \nand so many other things\n
      6. \n
    \n

    \nincase you missed the other series, don't worry you can always go back and read them up\n

    \n
    \nLink to previous series\n
    \n

    \nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1\n

    \n

    \nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 2\n

    \n

    \nNow lets go back to what we are really here for, blogging from your mobile phone\n

    \n

    \nWhat is blogging\n

    \n

    \n Blogging refers to writing, photography, and other media that is self-published online.\n

    \n

    \nSo basically you know what blogging is all about, its a way for a lot of people to express their feelings and share there ideas online.\n

    \n

    \nBlogging with jekyll\n

    \n

    \nyour blog posts live in a directory called _posts in the root of your site, so basically thats where you will add all your blog posts\n

    \n

    \nYour blog file names begin with \"year-month-date-your-title.md\"
    \nso when creating your post, always follow the order Year-month-date-title.md \n

    \n

    \nfor a detailed on how to write blog posts on jekyll please refer to this jekyll guide below

    \nLearn more about jekyll post\n

    \n

    \nPublishing your first post\n

    \n

    \nThe first step is to open your spck editor, The editor you downloaded in the first part of this series, open it and navigate to your _posts folder\n

    \n \n

    \nGo ahead and delete the post found there and create another one with

    \nYEAR-MONTH-DAY-TITLE.md format\n

    \n \n

    \nAfter you created the post
    \nadd your layout and title like this\n

    \n \n

    \nNow you can add anything to your blog post, after all you are now a blogger, after you are done with writting your post, just go ahead and commit your changes and then push them online like we learned in our previous post\n

    \n

    \nand there you have it, you just created your first post, go ahead and preview your new post online\n

    \n \n

    \n

    \n \n

    \n Previous posts from this series\n

    \n

    \nCreate a blog on your mobile phone part 1\n

    \n

    \n [create a blog on rour mobile phone with jekyll part 2](/blog/create-a-blog-on-your-mobile-phone-part-2)\n

    \n
    \nOther resources to learn from\n
    \n

    \n Getting Started With The Web \n

    \n

    \nJekyll tutorials home\n

    \n

    \nBlogging in jekyll\n

    \n

    \nthanks for reading.... \n

    "},{"template":{"inputPath":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","inputDir":"src","parsed":{"root":"","dir":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","stem":"index","path":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\src\\blog\\css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"extraOutputSubdirectory":"","outputDir":"public","linters":[],"transforms":[],"plugins":{},"paginationData":{},"isVerbose":true,"isDryRun":false,"writeCount":0,"skippedCount":0,"wrapWithLayouts":true,"fileSlug":{"inputPath":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","cleanInputPath":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","dirs":["blog","css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases"],"parsed":{"root":"","dir":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","base":"index.md","ext":".md","name":"index","extname":".md","basename":"index.md","dirname":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","stem":"index","path":"blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","absolute":"C:\\Users\\welcome\\Documents\\spruce-blog\\blog\\css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases\\index.md","isAbsolute":false},"filenameNoExt":"index"},"fileSlugStr":"css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases","filePathStem":"/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index","_templateRender":{"engineNameOrPath":"./src/blog/css-flexbox-and-some-use-cases/index.md","inputDir":"src","includesDir":"src/_includes","parseMarkdownWith":"liquid","parseHtmlWith":"liquid","_engineName":"md","useMarkdown":true},"inputContent":"---\r\ndate: 2020-12-25\r\ntitle: Css flexbox and some use cases \r\nauthor: Spruce\r\nsummary: >\r\n Learn about css flex box and how to implement this layout model with some use cases \r\npreview: img/preview.png\r\nsharing:\r\n twitter: Css flexbox and some use cases\r\n facebook: Css flexbox and some use cases\r\n---\r\n\r\n

    \r\nIn this quick article, we are going to learn what and how to use css flexbox with some use cases of flexbox \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWhat is Css Flexbox?\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nIn the flex layout model, the children of a flex container can be laid in any direction, and can \"flex\" their sizes, either growing to fill unused space or shrinking to avoid overflowing the parent. Both horizontal and vertical alignment of the childern can be easily manipulated.\r\n\r\n- well thats according to the spec...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nfrom the css flexbox specification above, you see that flexbox is a layout model which can be used to lay out the children of a container easily... \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFlex Container\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThe flex container takes the css property and value display: flex or display: inline-flex and it is the box generated by an element with a computed display of flex, children of this container are called flex items\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFlex containers are not block containers ( containers that have \"display: block\" set on them), therefore some properties like:
    \r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nfloat, and clear\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nvertical-align\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\n::first-line and ::first-letter\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\nwill not have any effect on flex-items (you won't even know they are there)\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFloats and vertical-align css properties do not have any effect on flex items, \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 1\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 2\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n.flex-container {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  \r\n}\r\n.flex-item {\r\n  float: left; // this will have no effect\r\n  vertical-align: middle; // this will have no effect too\r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nFlex items\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\nhello i am a flex item too\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 1\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 2\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 3\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nHow many flex items do we have from the above code? Well you might say THREE, but its actually FOUR. Plain text that are not wrapped in any html tag are also regarded as flex items\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nFrom the preview(when display: flex; is added to the flex-container) above you see that Four items are laid out side by side, that means anything placed in a flex-container as a direct child is a flex item...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<!-- anything placed here as a direct child is a flex item -->\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n.flex-container {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  \r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nSome Flexbox Use Cases\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nFlexbox reponsive header\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nFlexbox can be used to solve many design problems both complex and simple design problems with a few lines of css, one of this is a responsive website header

    \r\ntake a look at the responsive website header below \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n{% codepen \"Spruce_khalifa\" \"Responsive header with flexbox\" \"ExgbxeP\" %}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFlexbox Card component\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nLets say you are creating a card component... \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n...and you always want the footer to stay at the bottom, no matter the length of your text... Yep css flexbox can do just that with a single line of code\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\narticle {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  flex-direction: column;\r\n}\r\n// styles for the header and footer\r\np {\r\n  flex-grow: 1;\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nCheck it out on codepen...\r\n
    \r\nyou just need to add the flex-grow: 1; to the card content and it will always grow to fill the available spaces\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n{% codepen \"Spruce_khalifa\" \"Flex grow\" \"GRjogZX\" %}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nOrdering Elements\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nSay you want to flip a component, like the Card component we created ealier, you want the footer part to come first and the header to go last, yep flexbox can do that...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n\r\n// styles for the component\r\n footer {\r\n  order: -1; // make the footer come first\r\n   }\r\n header {\r\n   order: 2; // make the header go last\r\n   }\r\n    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nthe main thing here is the order property here, the preview should look like this one below\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nCenter An Element\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nOne of the cool things about css flexbox is that you can center an element with ease \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<div class=\"c-card\">\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n</div>\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n\r\n// styles for the component\r\n .c-card {\r\n   // some css\r\n   display: flex;\r\n   align-items: center; // center item vertically\r\n   justify-content: center; // center item horizontally\r\n }\r\n    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nand boom that should do the trick...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\nBrowser Support\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nIf you want to support older browsers, you should check the browser support level from caniuse.com\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n{% caniuse \"flexbox\" %}\r\n\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nOther Resources\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nCss flexbox W3c\r\n\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nComplete guide to css flexbox\r\n\r\n

    \r\n \r\n

    \r\nagain thanks for reading...\r\n

    ","frontMatter":{"content":"\r\n

    \r\nIn this quick article, we are going to learn what and how to use css flexbox with some use cases of flexbox \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nWhat is Css Flexbox?\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n\r\nIn the flex layout model, the children of a flex container can be laid in any direction, and can \"flex\" their sizes, either growing to fill unused space or shrinking to avoid overflowing the parent. Both horizontal and vertical alignment of the childern can be easily manipulated.\r\n\r\n- well thats according to the spec...\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nfrom the css flexbox specification above, you see that flexbox is a layout model which can be used to lay out the children of a container easily... \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFlex Container\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nThe flex container takes the css property and value display: flex or display: inline-flex and it is the box generated by an element with a computed display of flex, children of this container are called flex items\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFlex containers are not block containers ( containers that have \"display: block\" set on them), therefore some properties like:
    \r\n

      \r\n
    1. \r\nfloat, and clear\r\n
      2. \r\n
    2. \r\nvertical-align\r\n
      3. \r\n
    3. \r\n::first-line and ::first-letter\r\n
      4. \r\n
    \r\nwill not have any effect on flex-items (you won't even know they are there)\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\nFloats and vertical-align css properties do not have any effect on flex items, \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 1\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 2\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n.flex-container {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  \r\n}\r\n.flex-item {\r\n  float: left; // this will have no effect\r\n  vertical-align: middle; // this will have no effect too\r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nFlex items\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\nhello i am a flex item too\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 1\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 2\r\n</li>\r\n<li class=\"flex-item\">\r\nItem 3\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nHow many flex items do we have from the above code? Well you might say THREE, but its actually FOUR. Plain text that are not wrapped in any html tag are also regarded as flex items\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nFrom the preview(when display: flex; is added to the flex-container) above you see that Four items are laid out side by side, that means anything placed in a flex-container as a direct child is a flex item...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n 
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<ul class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<!-- anything placed here as a direct child is a flex item -->\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n.flex-container {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  \r\n}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nSome Flexbox Use Cases\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nFlexbox reponsive header\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nFlexbox can be used to solve many design problems both complex and simple design problems with a few lines of css, one of this is a responsive website header

    \r\ntake a look at the responsive website header below \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n{% codepen \"Spruce_khalifa\" \"Responsive header with flexbox\" \"ExgbxeP\" %}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nFlexbox Card component\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nLets say you are creating a card component... \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article class=\"flex-container\">\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\n...and you always want the footer to stay at the bottom, no matter the length of your text... Yep css flexbox can do just that with a single line of code\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\narticle {\r\n  display: flex;\r\n  flex-direction: column;\r\n}\r\n// styles for the header and footer\r\np {\r\n  flex-grow: 1;\r\n}\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nCheck it out on codepen...\r\n
    \r\nyou just need to add the flex-grow: 1; to the card content and it will always grow to fill the available spaces\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n{% codepen \"Spruce_khalifa\" \"Flex grow\" \"GRjogZX\" %}\r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n
    \r\nOrdering Elements\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nSay you want to flip a component, like the Card component we created ealier, you want the footer part to come first and the header to go last, yep flexbox can do that...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n\r\n// styles for the component\r\n footer {\r\n  order: -1; // make the footer come first\r\n   }\r\n header {\r\n   order: 2; // make the header go last\r\n   }\r\n    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n\r\n

    \r\nthe main thing here is the order property here, the preview should look like this one below\r\n

    \r\n\r\n

    \r\n
    \r\nCenter An Element\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nOne of the cool things about css flexbox is that you can center an element with ease \r\n

    \r\n
    \r\n\r\n<!-- html code -->\r\n<div class=\"c-card\">\r\n<article>\r\n<header>\r\n<!-- card header -->\r\n</header>\r\n<p>\r\n<!-- article content goes in here -->\r\n</p>\r\n<footer>\r\n<h2>\r\n<!-- card footer items goes here -->\r\n</h2>\r\n</footer>\r\n</article>\r\n</div>\r\n<!-- css codes -->\r\n\r\n// styles for the component\r\n .c-card {\r\n   // some css\r\n   display: flex;\r\n   align-items: center; // center item vertically\r\n   justify-content: center; // center item horizontally\r\n }\r\n    \r\n\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nand boom that should do the trick...\r\n

    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n
    \r\nBrowser Support\r\n
    \r\n

    \r\nIf you want to support older browsers, you should check the browser support level from caniuse.com\r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n

    \r\n{% caniuse \"flexbox\" %}\r\n\r\n
